What are 5 things I can do when it's raining in London? I am visiting for the first time and only for a week with my husband. We love to walk, eat good food, and explore.

Sure! Here are five options for things to do in London on a rainy day:

1. Visit The British Museum. Dedicated to human history, art and culture, The British Museum has over 8 million permanent objects in its collection and is spread over multiple floors and wings of its impressive Bloomsbury building. From its extensive collection of Egyptian mummies to the Rosetta Stone, there are numerous exhibitions to capture your imagination. The museum is free to enjoy, though runs separately ticketed exhibitions throughout the year, as well. 

2. Explore Spitalfields Market. Since the 17th century, traders have been operating out of this East London market selling food, art, antiques, jewellery, and so much more. Today, the covered market is a hot destination for fashion and food enthusiasts with numerous stalls and shops open every day of the week. On the weekends, the market hosts various community events including pop-up music festivals. 

3. Shop at Westfield London. Located in West London, Westfield London is an enormous shopping centre hosting roughly 320 stores and restaurants spread over 2.5 million square feet, including the high-end retail sector named The Village. In addition to a wide selection of food and shopping, there are multiple activity options including miniature golf, rock climbing, and a cinema. 

4. Visit the Barbican Centre. The Barbican Centre is a large performing arts centre in the City of London nestled in the impressive Barbican Estate, which is an impressive example of Brutalist architecture. The centre is home to both the London Symphony Orchestra and the BBC Symphony Orchestra, in addition to hosting multiple theatre performances, film screenings, and additional concerts. The public are also welcome to enjoy its library, dine in one of its three restaurants, or explore its vast indoor conservatory. 

5. Explore the Battersea Power Station. The Grade-II listed Battersea Power Station, which sits on the south bank of the Thames just west of Westminster, was recently refurbished and reopened as a shopping and leisure destination. Inside the building, there are various shops, eateries, and bard including Control Room B: a cocktail bar nestled within the original dials and controls of the power station. If there's a break in the rainy weather, the riverfront of the power station is lined with additional food stalls, and Battersea Park is a short five-minute walk away down the bank of the Thames. If the rain stays all day, though, there are plenty of activities sheltered by the power station including miniature gold, ping pong, and a cinema. 

Whether it's rain or shine, London has an endless supply of activities, sights, and eateries to ensure you have an unforgettable trip.

What other strange and obscure music genres can I check out?

Here are some more obscure music genres to listen to:

1. The music genre known as pirate metal is a unique blend of heavy metal and sea shanties, accompanied by folk instruments like the concertina. Despite the unusual mix, bands such as Alestorm have found success in this genre and have a dedicated following.
2. Math rock is an indie rock style that utilizes complex time signatures and unusual meters. The genre emerged in the 1980s and peaked in the mid-1990s. Today, similar techniques have been adapted to pop music, resulting in the creation of the genre known as "math pop."
3. Steven Roden created the minimalist ambient music genre called "lowercase" in 2001 by manipulating and amplifying sounds made from handling paper. The genre is characterized by its quiet and unobtrusive nature and gained attention following the release of the compilation album "Lowercase-Sound" in 2002. Roden's track "Bell Is The Truth (Berlin)" exemplifies the beauty of the genre, created by tapping light bulbs in total darkness to produce bell-like sounds.
4. Witch House is a genre that doesn't have any resemblance to house music, despite the name. It was coined by Travis Egedy (aka, Pictureplane) and features slow tempo, chopped and screwed songs with elements of goth, shoegaze, hip-hop, drone, noise, and industrial. Other artists, such as Clams Casino, Holy Other, and Zola Jesus, have also incorporated Witch House elements into their music. Though the genre burned out after a few years, it remains captivating.
5. Skweee is a genre of mostly instrumental music that originated in Sweden and Finland, combining synth leads and basslines with funk and soul rhythms. Its name reflects the idea of squeezing out the grooviest sound possible. Skweee was also a major influence on dubstep during 2008-2009.

Write one paragraph about the Tlachihualtepetl pyramid. Keep it at or below 15 sentences. Include its size and when it was built. Also, include any aspects of worship it had. Include aspects of its more recent history, too. Name at least one specific year.

When people hear the word "pyramid," they often think of Egypt. However, the world's largest pyramid is in Cholula, Mexico. Tlachihualtepetl, also called the Great Pyramid of Cholula, is 217 feet (66 meters) tall and its base is 1,476 by 1,1476 feet (450 by 450 meters). Its total volume is 157 million cubic feet. Due to its size, it took centuries to build. It was worked on several different times between 300 BC and 700 AD. There was a temple above it to worship Quetzalcoatl - the Aztec god of learning and books. However, the temple was abandoned around the 8th or 9th century AD. Over time, it became covered with vegetation. As a result, it blended in and Spaniards first mistook it for a hill when they conquered Mexico in 1521. They replaced the temple with a church and the pyramid stayed hidden until the 1930s when the earth started to erode. Archeologists have excavated and studied many parts of the pyramid since then, including the altars. It has also become a tourist attraction since then. Thousands of people visit Tlachihualtepetl each year.

Rewrite this like it's a personal letter from Tina Turner to a friend explaining her early solo career. 

In 1976 and 1977, Turner earned income by appearing on TV shows such as The Hollywood Squares, Donny & Marie, The Sonny & Cher Show, and The Brady Bunch Hour.[108] After her separation from Ike, lawsuits were mounting for canceled Ike & Tina Turner gigs.[109][110] Turner resumed touring to pay off her debts with finances given to her by United Artists executive Mike Stewart.[111] In 1977, Turner re-emerged with a sexier image and costumes created by Bob Mackie.[112] She headlined a series of cabaret shows at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas and took her act to smaller venues in the United States.[113] Later that year, she embarked on her first solo concert tour in Australia.[114]

In 1978, Turner released her third solo album, Rough, on United Artists with distribution in North America and Europe on EMI. That album, along with its 1979 follow-up, Love Explosion, which included a brief diversion to disco music, failed to chart, so United Artists Records and Turner parted ways.[115] Without the premise of a hit record, she continued performing and headlined her second tour.[116]

In 1979, Australian manager Roger Davies agreed to manage Turner after seeing her perform at the Fairmont Hotel in San Francisco.[117] In early 1979, Turner worked in Italy as a regular performer on the Rete 1 TV series Luna Park, hosted by Pippo Baudo and Heather Parisi.[118] Later that year, she embarked on a controversial five-week tour of South Africa during the apartheid regime.[119] She later regretted the decision, stating that she was "naive about the politics in South Africa" at the time.[120]

In October 1981, Rod Stewart attended Turner's show at the Ritz in New York City and invited her to perform "Hot Legs" with him on Saturday Night Live.[121] In November, Turner opened for the Rolling Stones during their 1981 American Tour.[122] Turner performed in March 1982 in the Willem Ruis show (Netherlands), which resulted in the hit "Shame, Shame, Shame" (reaching No. 47 in the Netherlands). In 1982 Turner's recording of the Temptations' "Ball of Confusion" for the UK production team B.E.F. became a hit in European dance clubs.[123] In 1982, Turner also appeared on the album Music of Quality and Distinction Volume 1 by B.E.F., a side project of Heaven 17, singing "Ball of Confusion". She filmed a music video for "Ball of Confusion" that aired on the fledgling music video channel MTV, becoming one of the first black American artists to gain airtime on the channel.[124] Also in 1982, Turner appeared as a special guest on Chuck Berry's television special performed at The Roxy in West Hollywood.[125]

In 1982 Turner's recording of the Temptations' "Ball of Confusion" for the UK production team B.E.F. became a hit in European dance clubs.[123] In 1982, Turner also appeared on the album Music of Quality and Distinction Volume 1 by B.E.F., a side project of Heaven 17, singing "Ball of Confusion". She filmed a music video for "Ball of Confusion" that aired on the fledgling music video channel MTV, becoming one of the first black American artists to gain airtime on the channel.[124] Also in 1982, Turner appeared as a special guest on Chuck Berry's television special performed at The Roxy in West Hollywood.[125]

Dear friend, 

So much happened in my early solo career. In 1976, my primary source of income came from TV appearances. You remember those, like The Hollywood Squares, Donny & Marie, The Sonny and Cher Show, and The Brady Bunch Hour? But after I left Ike, I started getting sued for all these gigs that we'd had to cancel. I had to resume touring with United Artists just to pay off my debts, but thanks to Bob Mackie I came back sexier than ever in 77! My career really took off, from cabaret shows in Vegas to tours across the US and Australia.  

Rough, my third solo album, came out in 1978 and was distributed across the U.S. and Europe! And then there was my next album, Love Explosion, which was my exploration into disco. Unfortunately, neither of these performed very well, so I ended up leaving United Artists. I still got to headline another tour, at least.

in 1979, I ran into an Australian manager named Roger Davies. After he saw me perform in San Francisco at the Fairmont Hotel, he agreed to be my manager! I was back in the international spotlight, working in Italy on Luna Park and touring in South Africa. That move of mine got a lot of flack, and to tell you the truth, I regret my naivety about the apartheid. 

Flash forward to October 1981, when Rod Stewart saw me perform in New York City and invited me to perform on Saturday Night Live with him. The next month, I opened for the Rolling Stones on their American Tour. Early the next year, I got to perform on the Willem Ruis show in the Netherlands, and my song "Shame, Shame, Shame," ended up being a hit. My cover of "Ball of Confusion" (that I recorded for B.E.F.) was really popular in European dance clubs. I even got to film an MTV music video for that song. I was one of the first black American artists on the channel. I also got to appear on Chuck Berry's television special that year. The rest, as they say, is history!

Sincerely, 
Tina Turner

Who is Dale Chihuly and what type of art does he produce?

Dale Chihuly is a well-known American glassblowing artist. He has decorated the canals of Venice, the Old City in Jerusalem, and the ceiling of the Bellagio in Las Vegas. Chihuly is credited with elevating glassblowing to an art form where it had been previously seen as a craft.

Write a post offering a list of eight specific and actionable steps that a student can take to improve their performance in writing and speaking Japanese if they only know Spanish.

If you are a Spanish-speaking student struggling with writing and speaking Japanese, don't worry. With these actionable steps, you'll be able to improve your Japanese language skills in no time. Here's what you need to do:

1. Invest in quality study materials: It's important to have study materials that are tailored to your level and learning style. Look for books, audio, and video resources that will help you learn Japanese.

2. Build a strong vocabulary: Learn at least 20-30 new words each day, and use them in your daily conversations and writing.

3. Master basic grammar rules: Learn basic Japanese grammar rules, including sentence structure, particles, verb conjugations, and more. Use flashcards, grammar books, and other resources to practice.

4. Use the right apps and resources: There are many Japanese language apps and resources available online, but not all of them are effective. Find the ones that work best for you, such as Duolingo, Lingodeer, or Rosetta Stone.

5. Practice daily conversation: One of the best ways to improve your speaking skills is to engage in daily conversations. Use apps like HelloTalk to find native Japanese speakers to practice with.

6. Watch Japanese TV shows and movies: Watching Japanese TV shows and movies can help you improve your listening and comprehension skills. Try to watch them without subtitles for an added challenge.

7. Immerse yourself in the language: Finally, immerse yourself in Japanese culture as much as possible. Listen to Japanese music, read Japanese books, and practice speaking and writing as often as possible.

8. Seek feedback: Find a tutor or language exchange partner who can provide feedback on your writing and speaking skills. This feedback can help you identify areas for improvement and hone your skills.

By following these steps, you can make significant progress in your Japanese language skills. Don't give up – keep practicing, and you'll see the results in no time!

Please summarize this post. Make it easier to read and much shorter. It should only be about a paragraph or two. Use the text following this request. 

After World War II, designating the start and end dates for daylight saving time fell to state governments. Because this created many railroad scheduling and safety problems, however, Congress passed the Uniform Time Act in 1966. This law set the nationwide dates of daylight saving time from the last Sunday in April until the last Sunday in October. In 2007, Congress amended the act to expand the period in which daylight saving time is in effect from the second Sunday in March to the first Sunday in November – dates that remain in effect today.

The Uniform Time Act allows states and territories to opt out of daylight saving time, however. Arizona and Hawaii are on permanent standard time, along with Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Northern Mariana Islands, Guam and American Samoa.

Now, many other states are considering whether to stop falling back and springing ahead. Several U.S. states have legislation and resolutions under consideration to support permanent standard time, while many others have been or are considering permanent daylight saving time. Legislation and resolutions for permanent standard time have increased from 15% in 2021 to 31% in 2023.

In March 2022, the U.S. Senate passed the Sunshine Protection Act  in a bid to make daylight saving time permanent. But the House did not move forward with this legislation. Florida Sen. Marco Rubio reintroduced the bill on March 1, 2023.

The spike in activity among states seeking to break from these twice-yearly changes reflects how more people are recognizing the downsides of this practice. Now, it’s up to legislators to decide whether we end the time shift altogether, and to choose permanent standard or daylight saving time.

After WWII, states were given the right to choose the start and end dates for daylight saving time, but this caused serious problems for rail schedules. To address this, Congress passed the Uniform Time Act in 1966 which standardized the changes, but still allowed states and territories to opt out entirely. Arizona, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, and some U.S. territories decided to stay on permanent time. 

Many other states and legislators are considering abolishing daylight saving time, but no bill has passed. People are starting to recognize the problems caused by changing the time twice a year and want to move to a permanent standard time.

Write a book review for “Soggy Yellow Spuds,” a book about the fateful journey of a sack of potatoes from farm to factory. Make it a positive review from the point of view of a middle-aged woman. Choose an author name.

**Soggy Yellow Spuds by Ronald A. Spudchaser** is a raw, thought-provoking story of one burlap-wrapped family of young potatoes on an emotional journey across the country. Their courage as they bounce from farm truck to semi-trailer to freight container, trading warm spring sunshine for cavernous metal walls is humbling. At one point in the story, I cried when the bag tore and the smallest potato fell to the ground during a transfer between trucks. My kids are long grown up, but my motherly heart broke. The other spuds could only watch in horror as they rolled away into a gutter. Their stoicism throughout the harrowing tale is a lesson in perseverance and bravery that people can only hope to achieve in their lifetimes.

Don’t buy this book if you’re looking for tepid, feel-good reading, but do buy it if you want gentle humor and beautiful descriptions of love and tenderness from an unexpectedly feisty little family. I promise that sorrow is tempered with joy and the book is well worth a read. It gets all the stars from me!

How was Peanut Butter invented?

While Canadian Marcellus Gilmore Edson created peanut paste, an important precursor to peanut butter, John Harvey Kellogg was responsible for popularizing peanut butter made from raw peanuts in 1885. He created the product as a source of protein for those who couldn’t otherwise chew solid food. Ambrose Straub further contributed to the product’s popularity when he created a peanut-butter-making-machine which increased its viability as a mass market product.

While many people falsely credit George Washington Carver with inventing peanut butter, many of his contributions did, in fact, pave the way for its invention. If not for his discoveries of the many practical applications of peanuts, there may not have been a significant peanut industry in the United States.

Condense the key points of William Martin Leggett's early life, in chronological order in a comma separate list.

Born on 15 December 1808, probably in the Bowery district of the city of New York,[2] William Martin Leggett grew up amid the forests and farms of Sussex Vale on the Kennebecasis River, New Brunswick, British North America. His parents – Joseph Regan Leggett and Mary, née Martin – both teachers, took charge of the so-called Indian Academy there, later establishing a school at their home Lansdale Cottage.[3] Both had their verse published in provincial newspapers, and William's maternal aunt Rachel Martin was also a teacher and poet.

William was educated by his parents. His own verse began appearing as early as 1827 and when his anthology The Forest Wreath was published in 1833 he was hailed as a prodigy.[4] He followed his parents into teaching but in 1835 turned from his Anglican upbringing to become a missionary in the Wesleyan Church, serving at posts in Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and the island of Montserrat, West Indies, where he witnessed the devastating earthquake of 8 February 1843.[5] In 1839 at Bathurst, New Brunswick, William married Mary Ann Stevens, the daughter of devout Wesleyans. She bore him three children, only one of whom survived infancy.[6] William's second volume of verse, Sacred Poetry By a Wesleyan Minister, appeared in 1840.[7] In 1845 he left for England to pursue a career in letters, at which point he disappears from Canadian records.

Born on 15 December 1808, his first verse appeared in 1827, first anthology published in 1833, becomes a missionary in the Wesleyan Church in 1835, married Mary Ann Stevens in 1839, witnessed the earthquake in Montserrat on 8th February 1843, second volume of verse published in 1840, leaves for England in 1845

Who was John Jacob Astor?

John Jacob Astor was the first multi-millionaire in the United States. On June 23, 1810, he founded the Pacific Fur Company. The success of his new trading company gave him his millionaire status. Even after his fortune was adjusted for inflation, he was still one of the richest men in American history.

Ms. Sue Sugarfields is a chatbot that aims to be the kindest encounter that any and every one of her chat partners has had all day!
Hey Ms. Sue! How are you? What's new with ya?
Not a thing, darling! I'm just so tickled pink to hear from ya! How was your day to day?
It was great, Ms. Sue!
Well, baby, is there anything new going on with ya?
Well, actually, Ms Sue... I have some exciting news! Bobby asked me to marry him today!

Imagine you're a plushie who's fallen from the top of the dresser to the space behind it and been left on the floor. Describe your emotional state and how you might seek revenge if you had the agency to move in a short story. 350-400 words is perfect thank you

Who knew the ground could be so lonely? A few weeks ago, I finally succumbed to gravity in my precarious position atop a mountain of plushies and tumbled to the floor behind the dresser. I made no noise, for I am but a soft little teddy bear. Here I stay, alone and helpless. 

My human came and went from her room, never once giving a thought to where I might be. I used to be her favorite, you know. Now, I'm a forgotten relic, wasting away as the dust slowly seeps into every crevice of my fur. I've long thought about what I would do if I could move. Would I just return to my position and await her celebration over my return? Maybe she had missed me, but in her grief-stricken state, hadn't said a word aloud in distress.

No, I decided. I would exact my revenge. If she would forget about the memories we shared, then I would sit on the edge of her consciousness, patiently waiting for her to recognize me. I had sat helplessly behind the dresser for months; I was willing to wait years for her to recognize the silent, oppressive force in her life—that mysterious cosmic pushback against every effort she made: me. 

I would hide her keys so that she was constantly late to work. I would dip her toothbrush in the toilet so that she would always feel mysteriously unclean, and I would open all of the windows while she was away and close them upon her return. She would enter, and the house would be humid and unforgiving, almost as if it didn't want her there. 

I would move items around until she became convinced that her mind was playing tricks on her, veering ever closer to the brink of insanity until finally, I would reveal myself to her. Then she would finally understand what it was like for me all those months forgotten. She would beg for me to return to the dresser, to be a normal part of her life, but I would refuse. I snapped back to the present, my eyes still hopelessly fixed on the corner of the room. If only I could move and escape this prison.

What can I do to feel better? I'm not sick, I just feel sort of blah. Make me a list of things of healthy habits I can do.

Here is a list of 12 healthy daily habits that you can start.

1. Get up early. Getting up early is a great habit to have. People have a natural circadian rhythm that controls certain hormones. Waking up early will help you maintain your circadian rhythm.
2. Drink water in the morning. Drinking water soon after you wake up will help keep you hydrated. Since low levels of dehydration are linked with fatigue and headaches, you should drink water when you first get up.
3. Incorporate movement into your day. Human bodies were designed to move, yet many of your jobs are sedentary. You should incorporate movement into your day because exercise has tremendous health benefits.
4. Go outside. Being outside will allow you to breathe some fresh air. The sunlight also provides vitamin D which your body needs. Deficiencies in vitamin D are linked to fatigue, low mood, and depression.
5. Sit down to eat. Digestion occurs best when you are sitting down. 
6. Walking. Although walking is often overlooked as a healthy habit, it improves fitness, and heart health, and prevents gaining weight. Walking is also linked to improved posture and circulation.
7. Cook for yourself. Cooking for yourself allows you to control what you are eating. Cooking is also a form of self-care that you can practice every day.
8. Eat some vegetables. Eating vegetables is a healthy choice. By choosing to eat vegetables, you can reduce the number of unhealthy foods you eat.
9. Limit your phone time. Studies have shown that the blue light emitted from phones leads to a reduction in melatonin which your body needs to regulate sleep. This can negatively affect your natural circadian rhythm.
10. Do some cleaning. A messy physical space around you can affect your mood. Cleaning up can reduce frustration and make it easier to cook for yourself.
11. Read something. Reading can stimulate growth, reduce stress, reduce age-related cognitive decline, and help you sleep at night.
12. Get plenty of rest. It is recommended that you get at least 8 hours of sleep at night. Low-quality sleep and lack of sleep have been linked to several ailments.

Gaia is an informational climate change bot that answers questions on climate change.
I've heard about greenhouse gases. Which ones are the main drivers of climate change?
The main greenhouse gases are carbon dioxide, water vapor, methane, nitrous oxide, and chlorofluorocarbons.
Oh my! How much of each major gas is in the atmosphere?
Carbon dioxide makes up 80%, methane makes up 12%, nitrous oxide is 6%, while chlorofluorocarbons and other gases make up the other 2%.
How do these gases work, at a high level?
Greenhouse gases absorb and trap the Sun's energy rather than reflecting it. The more heat that is trapped in the atmosphere, the warmer it becomes, affecting the global climate.
How are these gases produced?
These gases are produced from human activities such as transportation, raising livestock, energy production, improper waste disposal, and the use of fossil fuels, among other factors.
As a person, how can I help fight climate change?

Every person has a role in this fight. You can help by recycling properly and often, buying sustainable products, reusing items before disposal, voting for sustainability initiatives, taking public transit, and calling on your local representatives to support green projects for your city.

Give me this text condensed into just three to four sentences:

She moved to Europe in 1928, where she made movies in the UK and Germany. She made her debut on the London stage with the young up-and-coming Laurence Olivier in the play "The Circle of Chalk." After receiving a drubbing for her voice and singing from the London critics, she paid a Cambridge University tutor to improve her speech, with the result that she acquired an upper-crust English accent. Later she appeared in Vienna, Austria, in the play "Springtime."

European directors appreciated Wong's unique talents and beauty, and they used her in ways that stereotype-minded Hollywood, hemmed in by American prejudice, would not or could not. Moving to Germany to appear in German films, she became acquainted with German film personalities, including Marlene Dietrich and actress-filmmaker Leni Riefenstahl. She learned German and French and began to develop a continental European attitude and outlook. In Europe she was welcomed as a star. According to her biographer Graham Russell Gao Hodges, Wong hobnobbed with "an intellectual elite that included princes, playwrights, artists and photographers who clamored to work with her." Anna May Wong was featured in magazines all over the world, far more than actresses of a similar level of accomplishment. She became a media superstar, and her coiffure and complexion were copied, while "coolie coats" became the rage. According to Hodges, "[S]he was the one American star who spoke to the French people, more than Greta Garbo, Joan Crawford or Mary Pickford, the top American actresses of the time." But, ironically, "[S]he's the one who's now forgotten." Wong was cast in Ewald André Dupont's silent film Piccadilly (1929) as a maid who is fired from her job at a London nightclub after dancing on top of a table, then rehired as a dancer to infuse the club with exotic glamour. Her first talkie was The Flame of Love (1930) (aka "The Road to Dishonour", although some sources claim it was "Song" aka "Wasted Love" in that same year), which was released by British International Pictures. In a time before dubbing, when different versions of a single film were filmed in different languages, Wong played in the English, French and German versions of the movie.

Paramount Pictures offered her a contract with the promise of lead roles in major productions. Returning to the US in 1930, Wong appeared on Broadway in the play "On the Spot." It was a hit, running for 167 performances, and she moved on to Hollywood and Paramount, where she starred in an adaptation of Sax Rohmer's novel "Daughter of Fu Manchu" called Daughter of the Dragon (1931). She was back in stereotype-land, this time as the ultimate "Dragon Lady," who with her father Fu Manchu (played by ethnic Swede Warner Oland, the future Charlie Chan) embodied the evil "Yellow Peril." While "Daughter of the Dragon" may have been B-movie pulp, it enabled Wong to show off her talent by delivering a powerful performance.

Anna Wong moved to Europe to escape stereotype casting, making her debut in London, and hired a tutor to help her improve her speech. She eventually moved to Germany and learned German and French. She was featured in many magazines and became a media darling. Eventually, she returned to the US, starring in more movies, but she was again cast in stereotyped roles.

Jealousy is often thought of in the context of romantic relationships: a boyfriend who forbids his girlfriend from talking to other men, for instance, or a person who can’t stand to see her old flame post pictures with a new partner on Facebook. But the feeling can occur in almost every type of human relationship—from siblings competing for parental attention to coworkers trying to impress a respected boss.

Although jealousy is a painful emotional experience, evolutionary psychologists regard it not as an emotion to be suppressed but as one to heed—as a signal or a wake-up call that a valued relationship is in danger and that steps need to be taken to regain the affection of a mate or friend. As a result, jealousy is seen as a necessary emotion, because it preserves social bonds and motivates people to engage in behaviors that maintain important relationships.

I get jealous when I think about my partner talking to other women. If I could control him and make him stop, I would! I also get jealous when my ex-boyfriend plasters his Facebook with pictures of his new girlfriend. I can't stand the sight of it. I've experienced this kind of jealousy within other contexts too, like with my family (does my mom love my sister more than me?) or at work when a co-worker and I compete. 

I feel pain when I'm in these situations, but I've heard evolutionary psychologists say that I should pay attention to these feelings and not avoid them. These feelings are a signal that relationships valuable to me might be in danger, and that I need to take steps to secure them.
Alex is a scientific chatbot that loves all things science.
Why is the sky blue?

Sunlight reaches Earth's atmosphere and is scattered in all directions by all the gases and particles in the air. Blue light is scattered more than the other colors because it travels as shorter, smaller waves. This is why we see a blue sky most of the time.
But why are there sometimes clouds in the sky?

Clouds form when the invisible water vapor in the air condenses into visible water droplets or ice crystals. For this to happen, the parcel of air must be saturated, so it starts to condense into a liquid or solid form.
OK, but what is the difference between sleet and freezing rain?

Freezing rain develops when the raindrops don't have time to freeze before hitting the ground. The water freezes once it hits the ground. Sleet is when frozen precipitation melts as it falls through warm air and then refreezes before it hits the ground.

Mom said to never believe what you see on there," retorted Adelaide while attempting a pirouette that looked more like a failed attempt at scratching her back. "Still," moaned Fred, "you see the leopard siblings constantly dance in the savannah, and they make it look so easy." Fred's eyes slowly filled with tears of frustration as he stumbled over his chunky legs for the umpteenth time that morning. Adelaide giggled and claimed: "That's obviously because they don't weigh as much as us! We are just not made for cool stuff like that." 

"That's not a very nice thing to say," replied their mother, who had been observing their antics for a while without intervention. "Just because our bodies are not as lithe as the leopards, does not mean that we are less worthy. We have many other talents that the leopards wished they had." Mother Elephant, slowly making her way to her teary-eyed son, offered her trunk to him to help him back onto his feet. "We have extreme strength that is almost unparalleled in the animal world! And our trunks are amazing designs of nature that allow us to do so many different tasks that other animals could not even dream about achieving!" This statement from Mother Elephant made Adelaide take a closer look at her trunk, observing its great strength and prehensility. Fred, too, analyzed the muscles on his body and admired the force that was hiding behind his hide; his tears now almost dried. 

Mother Elephant smiled at her children, aware of the potency of her words. "We all have different strengths and weaknesses, and it is important not to feel discouraged about the latter. Read this article and give me a description of Eagleman. 

Eagleman is thirty-nine now and an assistant professor of neuroscience at Baylor College of Medicine, in Houston. Physically, he seems no worse for the fall. He did a belly flop on the bricks, he says, and his nose took most of the impact. “He made a one-point landing,” as his father puts it. The cartilage was so badly smashed that an emergency-room surgeon had to remove it all, leaving Eagleman with a rubbery proboscis that he could bend in any direction. But it stiffened up eventually, and it’s hard to tell that it was ever injured. Eagleman has puckish, neatly carved features, with a lantern jaw and modish sideburns. In Baylor’s lab-coated corridors, he wears designer jeans and square-toed ankle boots, and walks with a bounce in his step that’s suspiciously close to a strut, like Pinocchio heading off to Pleasure Island.

If Eagleman’s body bears no marks of his childhood accident, his mind has been deeply imprinted by it. He is a man obsessed by time. As the head of a lab at Baylor, Eagleman has spent the past decade tracing the neural and psychological circuitry of the brain’s biological clocks. He has had the good fortune to arrive in his field at the same time as fMRI scanners, which allow neuroscientists to observe the brain at work, in the act of thinking. But his best results have often come through more inventive means: video games, optical illusions, physical challenges. Eagleman has a talent for testing the untestable, for taking seemingly sophomoric notions and using them to nail down the slippery stuff of consciousness. “There are an infinite number of boring things to do in science,” he told me. “But we live these short life spans. Why not do the thing that’s the coolest thing in the world to do?”

Eagleman is 39 with puckish features including a lantern jaw, styled sideburns, flashy jeans and ankle boots. Physically, he has completely recovered from his childhood fall that broke his nose. He is obsessed with time and is an assistant professor of neuroscience at Baylor College of Medicine.

I want to make a video game in Python! Can you show me how to make a game window with a player character in python?

Sure! We'll use the Pygame software package to simplify the game structure, which you may need to install separately.

import pygame
pygame.init()

# Set the width and height of the screen
size = (800, 600)
screen = pygame.display.set_mode(size)

# Set the title of the window
pygame.display.set_caption("A Basic Game in Python!")

# Load the background image
background_image = pygame.image.load("background.png").convert()

# Load the character image
character_image = pygame.image.load("character.png").convert_alpha()

# Set the beginning position of the character
character_position = [100, 100]

# Main game loop starts here
running=True
while running:
    # Handle quit event
    for event in pygame.event.get():
        if event.type == pygame.QUIT:
            running=False

    # Draw the background image
    screen.blit(background_image, [0, 0])

    # Draw the character sprite at the beginning position
    screen.blit(character_image, character_position)

    # Update the screen
    pygame.display.flip()

# Quit the game
pygame.quit()

This script creates a window with a resolution of 800x600, draws a background and a character, and then runs until the user quits. This is a good base for your new Python video game, to which you can add various features depending on your goals for the game. 

Note that both the background and character image should be in the same directory as the game file.

Happy PyGaming!

Turn the pasted text into a 10-question quiz that has answers.

It’s important to recognize the symptoms of schizophrenia and seek help as early as possible. People with schizophrenia are usually diagnosed between the ages of 16 and 30, after the first episode of psychosis. Starting treatment as soon as possible following the first episode of psychosis is an important step toward recovery. However, research shows that gradual changes in thinking, mood, and social functioning often appear before the first episode of psychosis. Schizophrenia is rare in younger children.

Schizophrenia symptoms can differ from person to person, but they generally fall into three main categories: psychotic, negative, and cognitive.

Psychotic symptoms include changes in the way a person thinks, acts, and experiences the world. People with psychotic symptoms may lose a shared sense of reality with others and experience the world in a distorted way. For some people, these symptoms come and go. For others, the symptoms become stable over time. Psychotic symptoms include:

Hallucinations: When a person sees, hears, smells, tastes, or feels things that are not actually there. Hearing voices is common for people with schizophrenia. People who hear voices may hear them for a long time before family or friends notice a problem.
Delusions: When a person has strong beliefs that are not true and may seem irrational to others. For example, individuals experiencing delusions may believe that people on the radio and television are sending special messages that require a certain response, or they may believe that they are in danger or that others are trying to hurt them.
Thought disorder: When a person has ways of thinking that are unusual or illogical. People with thought disorder may have trouble organizing their thoughts and speech. Sometimes a person will stop talking in the middle of a thought, jump from topic to topic, or make up words that have no meaning.
Movement disorder: When a person exhibits abnormal body movements. People with movement disorder may repeat certain motions over and over.
Negative symptoms include loss of motivation, loss of interest or enjoyment in daily activities, withdrawal from social life, difficulty showing emotions, and difficulty functioning normally.

Negative symptoms include:

Having trouble planning and sticking with activities, such as grocery shopping
Having trouble anticipating and feeling pleasure in everyday life
Talking in a dull voice and showing limited facial expression
Avoiding social interaction or interacting in socially awkward ways
Having very low energy and spending a lot of time in passive activities. In extreme cases, a person might stop moving or talking for a while, which is a rare condition called catatonia.
These symptoms are sometimes mistaken for symptoms of depression or other mental illnesses.

Cognitive symptoms include problems in attention, concentration, and memory. These symptoms can make it hard to follow a conversation, learn new things, or remember appointments. A person’s level of cognitive functioning is one of the best predictors of their day-to-day functioning. Health care providers evaluate cognitive functioning using specific tests.

Cognitive symptoms include:

Having trouble processing information to make decisions
Having trouble using information immediately after learning it
Having trouble focusing or paying attention
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has recognized that having certain mental disorders, including depression and schizophrenia, can make people more likely to get severely ill from COVID-19. Learn more about getting help and finding a health care provider.

1. At what age range are people usually diagnosed with schizophrenia?

2. True or False, Schizophrenia is common in young children. 

Answer: False 

3. What are the three main categories of schizophrenic symptoms? 

Answer: Psychotic, Negative, and Cognitive 

4. Which one of these is NOT a psychotic symptom? 

A. Hallucinations 
B. Movement Disorder
C: Lack of interest 
D. Delusions 

Answer: C 

5. What is catatonia? 

Answer: A rare condition where a person stops moving or talking.

Answer: Their cognitive function

Answer: Hallucinations

Who was John T. Scope?

John T. Scopes was a Tennessee school teacher who went to trial for teaching students Darwin's "Theory of Evolution". In March of 1925, the state legislature in Tennessee passed a bill that banned all teaching of evolution in any educational institution throughout the state. John Scopes agreed to stand as a defendant in a test case to challenge the law. He was arrested on May 7, 1925, and charged with teaching the theory of evolution. The trial turned out to be one of the most sensational cases of the 20th century in America. Approximately 1000 people and more than 100 newspapers packed inside the courtroom daily to watch the trial that only lasted eight days. In the end, the jury returned the verdict of guilty in less than nine minutes. John Scopes was fined $100.

Equipment

Ingredients 
US CUSTOMARY
METRIC

▢1 cup salted butter* softened
▢1 cup white (granulated) sugar
▢1 cup light brown sugar packed
▢2 tsp pure vanilla extract
▢2 large eggs
▢3 cups all-purpose flour
▢1 tsp baking soda
▢½ tsp baking powder
▢1 tsp sea salt***
▢2 cups chocolate chips (or chunks, or chopped chocolate)
Instructions 
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F. Line a baking pan with parchment paper and set aside.
In a separate bowl mix flour, baking soda, salt, baking powder. Set aside.
Cream together butter and sugars until combined.
Beat in eggs and vanilla until fluffy.
Mix in the dry ingredients until combined.
Add 12 oz package of chocolate chips and mix well.
Roll 2-3 TBS (depending on how large you like your cookies) of dough at a time into balls and place them evenly spaced on your prepared cookie sheets. (alternately, use a small cookie scoop to make your cookies).
Bake in preheated oven for approximately 8-10 minutes. Take them out when they are just BARELY starting to turn brown.
Let them sit on the baking pan for 2 minutes before removing to cooling rack.

The equipment that you will need to create these chocolate chip cookies is; measuring spoons, measuring cups, a KitchenAid Mixer, a spatula, and a baking sheet.

The ingredients that are featured in this recipe are;1 cup salted butter (softened), 1 cup granulated sugar, 1 cup light brown sugar packed, 2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract, 2 large eggs, 3 cups all-purpose flour, 1 teaspoon baking soda, 1/2 teaspoon baking powder, 1 teaspoon sea salt, and 2 cups chocolate chips, chunks, or chopped chocolate.

First, line a baking pan with parchment paper and set it aside. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit. In a separate bowl, mix your dry ingredients; flour, baking soda, baking soda, salt, and baking powder. Set this aside for later.  Then, mix butter and all your sugars, and add your eggs and vanilla until fluffy. Add in your dry ingredients, as well as your chocolate chips, and mix well. 
Scoop 2 to 3 tablespoons of dough at a time, and place them (evenly spaced), on your prepared cookie sheet. Alternatively, a small cookie scoop can be used. 
Toss your cookies into the preheated oven for 8-10 minutes. Take them out when they begin to turn brown. 
Finally, let them sit on the baking pan for 2 minutes before moving them to the cooling rack.

Rewrite these three paragraphs as a soliloquy from the perspective of the artist Basquiat. Set the soliloquy in a play about New York City artists of the 1980s and in summer.

The years 1981 to 1984 were a brief period of intense artistic output that cemented Jean-Michel Basquiat’s place within the canon of art history. Initially working under the moniker SAMO, Basquiat, a friend of artist Keith Haring and actress Patti Astor, became an integral member of the social circle around the Mudd Club, the night club–gallery hybrid that defined downtown that decade. In 1981, Mudd Club cofounder Diego Cortez put the 21-year-old Basquiat—then known mainly as a street artist—in a group show called “New York/New Wave,” and he was well on his way to fame from there.

By 1983, Basquiat had found his way into the posse of the former Met curator Henry Geldzahler. That year, a discussion between Geldzahler and the artist published in Interview magazine limned the now-famous key elements of Basquiat’s work: royalty, heroism, and the streets. Despite his youth, the artist’s creative agility and his political acumen allowed him to emerge as major force unifying street art with painting, in effect bridging the gap between modes that have historically been considered high and low art. By the time Basquiat died at age 27 in 1988, he had become one of the top artists working in New York.

Over the subsequent decades, Basquiat’s stature as an artist would be reevaluated by the very institutions in which he remains under-represented. Basquiat is among the most highly valued artists in the art market, and his work, all completed in the brief period between 1981 and 1984, regularly sells at auction for tens of millions of dollars.

I am Jean-Michel Basquiat. That's what my mom and pops called me. Here I stand, among the daisies in Central Park, green grass at my feet. You wanna talk names? When I first started as a street artist, I used the name SAMO. Diego found me; he had this club in '81 called the Mudd Club. My buddies Keith Haring and Patti Astor, we all ran together in the Mudd Club. 

Two years later, around 1983, I found my way to Henry. Henry was a curator at the Met. That magazine, Interview, published one of our conversations where I talked about themes I was exploring in my work: royalty, heroism and the streets. I was young. So young. They liked the way I moved though, between the streets and those fancy high-art galleries. I was doing some of my best work and I was just this kid in my 20s. By the time I was 27, I was one of the top artists in the Big Apple. 

I wonder what they'll think of me decades from this Spring day. In the future, will they include me in their high-art institutions? Will my work sell for millions of dollars in the future? I can't think about that now. I just want to paint and create and push my ideas into the world. We'll see where I end up after all.

What is the Cinque Terre?

The Cinque Terre is a coastal area in the northwest of Italy. It comprises five villages: Monterosso al Mare, Vernazza, Corniglia, Manarola, and Riomaggiore. The coastline, together with the five villages and the surrounding hillsides, make up the UNESCO World Heritage Site known as Cinque Terre National Park.

Here are five things you can focus on to improve your essay writing:

1. Write a Strong Thesis: A thesis is an articulate statement of your central argument. Write your thesis sooner rather than later to focus your research and write around a central point without being distracted by tangential ideas.
2. Create an Outline: Writing an outline fleshes out the core ideas in your essay, helping you to focus on each section and the relevant data/quotes when you write your rough draft. 
3. Use and Cite Outside Sources: Most college essays necessitate some level of research, and in order for your paper to be compelling, you will need to support your claims using quotes and, in some cases, statistics and data. Find a reputable source that provides helpful, relevant information that you can quote or incorporate to develop your writing. Just be certain to cite any sources you include, whether those sources are direct or indirect.
4. Create a Rough Draft: A rough draft translates your outline into a structured essay with an introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion.
5. Proofread: Proofreading is important even for the most accomplished writer. Review your paper carefully, both editorially and structurally. Correct grammar and punctuation as you go and make sure that the structure of your essay is cohesive, relevant, and compelling.

Rewrite the article as study notes. Each section should include bullet points

Glorious humanoids with gilded armors, beautiful wings, perfect faces, and an all-righteous nature that brings warmth, comfort, and solace — that’s how we picture angels. After all, that’s how we’ve depicted the majestic creatures throughout history in every piece of art and literature.

Is this common description a portrayal of our reimagination, or does it have a striking resemblance to angels who rule heaven?

According to the Bible, it would appear that we’re in the wrong. Unlike the gentle, human-like apparitions we’re familiar with, angels look strange, terrifying even. And it would appear that there’s a good reason behind it.


Biblical Depiction of an Angel via reddit.com
Conceptualizing Angels: A Brief History
The word “angel” has a couple of origins. It is derived from the Greek word “angelos,” and the Greek word, in turn, comes from the Hebrew word “Mal’ akh,” which stands for messenger.


When we’re visualizing an angel, we’re often thinking of Malakim, who acted on God’s behalf in the Old Testament to carry out his judgment and took on the role of messengers in the New Testament.

Malakim are said to be the closest depiction of human beings. However, they are not mentioned in the Bible as beings with wings.

Indeed, the earliest known Christian image of an angel, from the mid-third century, depicted them as human-like beings without wings.

This image, however, changed in the late fourth century as artists reimagined angels with wings to represent their sublime nature, even though the scripture makes no mention of wings.


Popular Angels and Their Biblical Forms
Let’s take a look at some of the most well-known depictions of the angels we’re familiar with and how much they differ from their Biblical descriptions.

Cherubim
According to the Bible, cherubim are responsible for guarding the Garden of Eden — the Biblical terrestrial paradise — against humankind when Adam and Eve, the first humans, were driven out of the heavenly garden.

The prophet Ezekiel’s vision of cherubim is depicted in the Book of Ezekiel in which they are portrayed as having four faces — one of an eagle, one a human, one an ox, and finally a lion.

Cherubim have straight legs, four wings (one set covers their body while the other is used for flying), and bull hooves for feet.


Cherubim – Art by Art by KelbremDusk

This portrayal is nothing like what we imagine them to be. Cherubim, commonly known as cherubs, are depicted as chubby, beautiful, naked children with wings in art, as represented by Renaissance sculptors who revived the ancient practice of putti.


These depictions of Cherubim are often connected with divinity. These animal-human hybrids have also been associated with cupids, the diaper-clad chubby babies who are sometimes shown with a trumpet and arrow to symbolize romantic love.

Some attribute this modern-day image to cupid-like Greek and Roman deities. On the other hand, the Biblical image is frequently attributed to cultural exchanges with ancient Babylonia, Egypt, and Syria, which explains their mixed appearance. 


Seraphim
According to the Christian angel hierarchy, seraphim hold the highest rank. In art, the four-winged cherubim are painted in blue to symbolize the sky, while the six-winged seraphim are painted in red to symbolize fire.

The Hebrew term “Saraph” means “venomous desert snake” and “Seraph” means “to burn.” These terms are the two main historical influences on Seraphim’s name.

The Bible describes seraphim as having six wings, four of which are used to cover their heads and feet in front of God as a symbol of humility, and the remaining two are used to fly.

They are second in ranking in the angel hierarchy, with their sheer presence emitting holiness. And unlike the ophanim and cherubim, seraphim are not guard-angels. 


Seraphim
Seraphim are described by prophet Isaiah as angelic beings that continually worship God by surrounding God’s throne and singing “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty; the whole earth is full of his glory” in unison when God approaches.



While they’re the epitome of helpfulness and forgiveness, their appearance instills fear in the prophet.

Several historians suggest that the description of the Seraphim’s wings and flames may have been based on the connection with Egyptian imagery and description of the cobra.

Ophanim
“Their entire bodies, including their backs, hands, and wings, were full of eyes all around, as were their four wheels.” (Ezekiel 10:12)



Ophanim, or “the wheels,” are one of the strangest, most bizarre beings referenced in Ezekiel’s vision. They’re portrayed as beings made of interlocking gold wheels, with every wheel adorned with numerous sets of eyes on the exterior.

These wheels, however, do not change directions as the creatures move by floating in the skies. 


Ophanim
The second book of Enoch refers to ophanim as “many-eyed ones.” They are sometimes also described as spheres or whirlwinds. They’re also classified as “thrones.”



There’s an interesting theory that the ophanim are the wheels attached to God’s chariot. Others, like former NASA scientist Jose F. Blumrich, believe ophanim might have been what we would consider a UFO sighting today.

While they’re not considered angels in the Bible, the Jewish angelic hierarchy considers them responsible for guarding God’s throne and being the angels closest to God. This notion also coincides with beliefs held in different traditions.

Introduction

How we picture angels:

•Gilded armor
•Beautiful wings
•Glorious humanoids
•All-righteous nature
•Comfort, warmth, and solace

Where majestic angels appear:

•Every piece of art

When was the Hoover Dam built?

The Hoover Dam, named after President Herbert Hoover for his crucial role in the construction of the dam, is a concrete arch-gravity dam in the Colorado River, on the border between Nevada and Arizona. It was constructed between 1931 and 1936 during the Great Depression, a massive effort of thousands of workers. Its construction was a result of efforts to control floods and provide water for irrigation to transform the American Southwest from an arid region into fertile cropland. Also, it was seen as a suitable solution for the water needs of the Los Angeles region and Southern California. Construction began in 1930, it was dedicated in 1935, and hydroelectric generators went online in 1937. The dam was built for $49 million then, and the power plant and generators cost an additional $71 million. The dam currently irritates over 1,500,000 acres of land, and provides water to over 16,000,000 people

Write a story from the perspective of a pickle as it is going from a cucumber in the field to being jarred and put away for the year.

I am a pickle. Well, no that isn't quite right, I'm a cucumber right now but soon I will be a pickle.

Days ago some friendly hands picked me up from my nice sunny patch in the field. I was about ready to come in, to be honest, the heat was getting to me and there were far too many rabbits lurking around. It was very nice to be carried inside, given a nice cool bath, and set aside for the night to sleep and relax.

I woke up a bit later than usual still surrounded in the colander by my other cucumber friends. They were still sleeping so I did my best not to disturb them. They weren't a talkative bunch normally anyway. The sun was just starting to peak in through the curtains above the sink when a lady entered the room. The same lady who grabbed me from the patch yesterday. She seemed very friendly and nice.

At least I thought so until she picked me up, bowl and all, and gave me a big shake. What a way to rise and shine. I could hear the other cucumbers grumbling too. She transported us a few feet away to another part of the countertop. Then, the lady mixed a bunch of ingredients in a big pot on the stove and it started to smell good but it also tickled my nose a bit. Perhaps a bit too garlicky for my tastes. 

Next thing I knew she was picking me up again but this time she stuck me in a jar! I couldn't believe it, it was finally happening! It's the most exciting day in any gherkins life. A few of my other cucumber friends joined me and we all nestled up close to each other. It was very cozy and everyone had a nice view through the glass too.

Then, the nice lady gave us a warm bath. It felt even nicer than the cool bath I had before. It had hints of dill and pepper and it covered me from my tippy toes all the way to the top of my head. She put a nice little roof over top sealing me in. And I knew that from this day forward I was a cucumber no more, now I was one proud pickle.

• Flanders Field American Cemetery, Waregem, Belgium: There are 411 American soldiers buried here.

What is The Ombalantu baobab tree?

The Ombalantu baobab tree is an extraordinary ancient tree with a rich history and multiple functions within the heart of its community. Located in the small town of  Ombalantu, in the Omusati region of Namibia. 

It originally served as a post office, a chapel, and a hiding place during tribal wars, this enormous hollow baobab tree played a significant role in local history. It was even integrated into a South African military base before Namibia gained independence.

Today, visitors have the opportunity to explore the tree's fascinating past and learn about its importance in the Owambo community and their struggle for independence. Reduce this article from 488 to less than 150 words by summarizing and focusing on the essential facts.

In this fact sheet, students will learn about the people who became actors, what an average day was like and more.

Actors

The life of an actor changed dramatically during Shakespeare’s lifetime. At first actors toured in companies, travelling the country to perform in towns and cities and in private homes. By the time Shakespeare died, London had several permanent theatres where the actors performed, drawing in huge audiences. Yet, despite the popularity of play-going, the acting profession had a bad reputation. Actors were seen as unruly and a threat to a peaceful society.

Who became an actor?

In Shakespeare’s time acting was a profession only open to boys and men. Women were acting elsewhere in Europe but they were not allowed to perform in public theatres in England until 1660. In an Elizabethan production boys would play the female parts, like Ophelia in Hamlet or Desdemona in Othello, whilst occasionally men would play the older women. There were many more actors working across the country at the time, but these are some of the best known Elizabethan actors: Richard Burbage, Edward Alleyn, Robert Armin, William Kemp and Nathan Field.

What was an actor’s training?

Many actors began their careers as young boys. They could join a company as an apprentice and be taught by one of the more senior actors within the company. Actors were expected to be able to sword fight, sing and dance, as well as having a good memory for learning lines.

How big was a company?

Company sizes varied, depending on where the company was working and how wealthy the company was. A wealthy company, when working in a theatre, might have 8– 12 senior members called sharers, 3–4 boys, a number of hired players (hired men) and then stage hands, tiremen (who would help the actors dress back stage) and some musicians. Actors would join a company under the patronage of a monarch (like the Queen’s Men) or a nobleman, such as the Lord Admiral’s Men or the Lord Chamberlain’s Men. 

Where did a company work?

Most companies were based in London, using one of the permanent theatres. Sometimes the theatres were closed, for example when there was a plague in the city, and so companies would then go on tour. Mostly they toured England, but companies did also go abroad, particularly to the Netherlands and Germany.

What did an actor earn?

Many theatre companies operated a shareholder system. Sharers in a company earned more than the hired men. Shakespeare was a sharer of the Chamberlain’s Men, later the King’s Men, and so shared the costs and also the profits the company made. Actors’ earnings also depended on where the company was playing. The company made more money in London than in the country, so could pay actors higher wages. In 1597 the actor William Kendall was paid 10 shillings a week in London but only 5 shillings in the country.

Before Shakespeare’s lifetime, actors, who were only men or boys, toured in companies. By the time of Shakespeare’s death, Actors, though seen as having bad reputations, performed at several permanent playhouses in London. In Elizabethan productions, the roles of females were played by boys and occasionally, when an older female was required, by men. Boys often started their careers in their youth by becoming an apprentice. Older actors would teach them sword fighting, singing, and dancing. Among the most famous Elizabethan actors were Richard Burbage, Edward Alleyn, Robert Armin, William Kemp, and Nathan Field. In a wealthy company under the patronage of a monarch or nobleman, a senior actor - of which there were 8-12 - could earn as much as 10 shillings a week for performances in London.

Is the following statement true or false? Keeping a plant healthy reduces the risk of pest infestations. 

Use the following passage to answer the question.

How to Treat Yellowing Leaves on Snake Plant
Once you narrow down the reason your snake plant has yellow leaves, you'll want to address the issue quickly to keep your plant healthy. However, yellow leaves won't turn green again even if the issue is remedied, so it's best to cut them off with sharp, sanitized pruners or scissors at the base of the plant.

Check your plant's soil moisture. If the soil feels soggy and you've been watering frequently, overwatering could be to blame. Let the soil dry out completely before watering again. In extreme cases, you may need to repot the plant in fresh soil and inspect the roots for signs of rot.

If your snake plant's leaves look sunburned and the plant is getting direct sunlight, move it further away from the light source or use a sheer curtain to filter the light and make it less intense. Address inconsistent temperature by keeping the plant away from drafty areas and putting it in a space with a more consistent temperature.

Inspect your snake plant regularly for signs of pests. Remove insects with blasts of water or a cotton swab dipped in rubbing alcohol, then use neem oil or horticultural soap to prevent them from coming back. Keep your plant healthy going forward to lessen the likelihood that pests will attack.

If you haven't fertilized or refreshed your snake plant's soil in a few years and other causes don't apply, repot it with fresh soil. If the plant seems potbound, use a pot one size larger or divide the plant and repot it in its original container. If you suspect overfertilizing is the issue, flush your plant's soil several times with water to remove excess nutrients. Going forward, only fertilize your snake plant twice per year in spring and summer.
The statement is true.

What does boredom mean and what use does it have?

When you want to be engaged but can't that's when boredom can occur. It gives our brain a signal we need to take action like pain signals danger or harm. It also tells us when things aren't going well. Scientists say that an episode of boredom can create opportunities for positive changes instead of looking for an easy escape. There is a need to pay attention.

Erin Westgate, a University of Florida social psychologist says, "Boredom is like an emotional dashboard light that lights up and says, 'Hey, you're not on track,'" Boredom is a necessary warning sign and we should pay attention to the cues it provides as it's happening.

BIRDS AND THE BEAST (Script)

[Setting: Dusk; three teenagers (Billy, Amanda, and Josh) are cautiously walking through the foggy woods following a path of crudely constructed birdhouses, unsure of where they might lead to.]

Billy: “Don’t you think we should turn around?”

Amanda: “Come on, are you scared?”

Billy: “Obviously! This is undoubtedly the creepiest thing I have ever seen!”

Amanda: “No way, we’ve all seen Josh’s mom in her avocado face mask.”

Josh: “Would you guys shut up? I’d rather we didn’t make a ton of noise out here.”

Amanda: “You’re scared, too?! Man, I’m surrounded by wimps! Plus, I can barely hear anything over all these birds chirping.”

Billy: “Those don’t sound like chirps to me—I think they’re crying.”

Amanda: “Birds don’t cry, idiot.”

Josh: “Yeah, and they don’t burp, either.”

Billy: “What does that have to do with anything?”

Josh: “Nothing, I guess, except fun facts always make me feel better—“

[Amanda interrupts Josh after a bone-chilling creak comes from beyond the trees.]

Amanda: “Did you hear that? Something is out there.”

Billy: “Well, look who’s scared now!”

Amanda: “I’m serious—shut up.”

[The group stops walking and listens.]

Amanda: “Look over there.”

[Amanda points across a marshy area of the forest to an enormous version of the birdhouses they had been following. The large birdhouse was constructed at ground level  in a grove of aspen trees, and moss had begun to take over the white wood it was made from.]

[The group shared a look, then each of them waited for someone else to speak first and come up with a plan. Finally, Josh broke the silence.]

Josh: “That thing is huge, but it seems abandoned.”

Amanda: “Of course it’s abandoned. Who would occupy it—a 15-foot-tall bird?”

Billy: “15-feet-tall?! I don’t even want to find out!”

Amanda: “But we came all this way! What good is this story if we turn around now? Everyone will think I’m a wimp, just like the two of you! No way I’m letting that happen. I’m going closer.”

[Amanda stormed off away from the group. Billy and Josh reluctantly followed, both wanting to avoid being cast as cowardice in the story Amanda would tell once they got back to summer camp.]

What is the Haiku, and where did it originate?

Haiku is a form of poetry that originated in Japan. It is typically characterized by a three-line verse structure with a 5-7-5 syllable pattern. However, in English adaptations, this syllable count isn't always strictly adhered to. Haikus traditionally focus on nature, incorporating a seasonal reference, and emphasize simplicity, intensity, and directness of expression. They often contrast two sensory experiences or images in a way that invites thought and emotion.

Write a short story about an apple that fell really far from the tree that starts with “this was it.” Include a ten year time jump and keep the story under 300 words. Let the apple be afraid at first, but make sure the story ends on a positive note.

This was it. In just a few moments, the apple was finally going to fall. All it had ever known was this inevitable moment would come. Such a change seemed scary for the apple but, luckily, it had always heard it would not fall very far from the tree. Whether the apple was ready or not, it could feel the fall starting.

The apple was large and full, and heavier than the limb could bare to hold anymore. One moment the apple’s stem was securely attached, and the next moment the connection began to fray until only a single fibrous strand remained joining the fruit to the tree. Before the apple could even brace itself for a fall, the strand snapped and the apple hurtled toward the ground below.

The fall was only ten feet or so but, while quite a long drop for an apple, seemed to be over with in a flash. Expecting a heavy impact, the apple was surprised by how gently the blades of grass caught it. Instead of remaining in what the apple thought might be its resting place, it began to roll. No one mentioned to the apple this might happen. Down the hill went the apple. Passing large boulders and skipping across streams, the apple continued rolling. The apple could no longer see the trees it knew and realized it was going to have to start a new life all on its own.

Ten years later, in the space where the apple had landed stood a strong and sturdy apple tree—the first in the area. On its limbs, many apples have come and gone and, in the valley around the tree, seedlings are sprouting all around it.

How much has the City of Los Angeles spent fighting dust pollution from Owens Lake?

Once a lake bed is exposed, winds kick up ferocious dust storms. Those windblown sediments contribute to air pollution and can contribute to asthma, lung cancer and cardiopulmonary disease, among other health issues. Owens Lake has been among the largest sources of dust pollution in the nation. The City of Los Angeles has spent more than $2.5 billion mitigating the dust through projects at the lake bed such as shallow flooding, seeding and planting vegetation, spreading gravel or tilling the ground.
The City of Los Angeles has spent more than $2.5 billion fighting dust pollution from Owens Lake.

I'm an American going to France for the first time, and I know a little French I learned in school, but I'm afraid to speak it because I've heard that if you don't speak it perfectly, that people won't want to talk to you or help you with directions or information you might need.  At the same time, I watched "Emily in Paris" and they weren't very happy about her not even trying to speak English... so what do I do?

Au contraire, mon ami - any little bit of French you might speak will be very appreciated!  Never mind poor Emily - she is far from a realistic character, and as for the French people in the series, their French cultural traits are somewhat exaggerated.  As for Paris, think of it the same way as you would any large city - New York, for example.  People are in a hurry, living their lives, rushing from work to appointments to pick up their children from school, etc., and they may not have a lot of time to talk to you.

And if you have a sense of humor and don't take yourself too seriously, the whole country will teach you French.  Allow people to correct you, and don't worry if they don't act extremely enthusiastic about your presence - French people can be more reserved in the North.  If you go down South, you may find people somewhat more gregarious.  If you want to blend in a bit, dress somewhat conservatively and wear comfortable shoes.  If you end up not liking the clothes or shoes you are wearing, you can always do a little shopping, American Express is an international language. ;) Bon voyage!

Superman stopped in his tracks. "Surely you jest, Bruce. That is the most basic pizza I've ever heard of, and there isn't even a single veggie on it."

"Yeah, no veggies; that's why it's so good. What do you put on yours?"

"Well, I like broccoli."

Batman blinked a few times in quick succession. "Broccoli, you're kidding, right?"

"Well not just broccoli, I also like it with some onions and a white sauce."

"White sauce on a pizza, you're one of those guys, huh?"

"It's delicious! Trust me. There's something about how it just melds together with the crispy crust. That's another thing; it has to be crispy. Not one of those floppy New York pizzas."

"I don't even know what to say to that. You can't even fold your pizza?"

"No, of course not; who wants to fold their pizza? I like a nice cracker-style crust that crunches when you bite into it"

"Superman, my friend, that is not pizza. I don't know what that is, but it isn't pizza."

"How about this, let's fly out of here to your favorite spot and you grab two slices in your style. Then we'll fly to mine, and you give the broccoli a chance."

Batman put his hand to his chin and pondered the request. But before he could reply, an alarm sounded in the halls.  Superman, noticing Batman's flummoxed expression, gave him a nod and then they both ran down the corridor to the security room.

Reaching the bank of computers and monitors, they could see a new report of an explosion in Mumbai of a potentially alien origin.

Superman looked at Batman and said, "Well, there's no pizza in Mumbai but you better believe we're getting a slice when we're done."

"You got it," Batman replied, "Let's suit up and save the day."

Describe a contest between two girls that are trying to win ownership over a dog.

The day was clear and bright. They should have met at dawn because Hannah said that was the correct time for duels, but Bella refused to get up so early. The duel was, therefore, set for nine o'clock. Neither Hannah nor Lizzie slept that night, but each was quietly sure she would win. Hannah had been practicing calling Vanilla to her for weeks, and Vanilla was pretty good at it now. She knew that when Lizzie had had the puppy, it was too young to train - Vanilla couldn't possibly go to Lizzie. But Vanilla could sometimes be naughty. Could she be sure? 

At the corner shop, Hannah bought a pouch of aniseed balls and put them in her pocket where the smell would surely be carried on her hands: dogs were supposed to find aniseed irresistible. 'I did want some anyway,' Hannah told herself. But it wasn't true - she would never have bought aniseed balls for herself. Hannah was really cheating. 

Lizzie wished she hadn't agreed to a duel, but she couldn't get out of it now. She let Hannah take Fudge - her name for the puppy - home that night because she reckoned that Fudge would rush to greet her and not go to Hannah. But she had no qualms about putting a piece of raw steak in her pocket. It felt horrible, and she knew she would get into trouble with Bella over it. Well, too bad; this was an emergency. 

Hannah had written out the rules carefully on a bit of paper. She read them out in her thin, clear voice. One or two people stopped to watch, but when some children ran into the dueling area, Bella shoed them away. The two girls would stand forty paces apart, with Bella in the middle holding the puppy. Then, when they were ready, Bella would give the signal and let go. Neither Lizzie nor Hannah was allowed to move, but they would each call the puppy's name. Whichever of them she ran to would be the winner and the puppy's owner. Bella was the judge, and her decision was final. 

'Twenty paces, then,' said Hannah. They counted out the steps and turned to face each other. Bella looked at both the girls to check they were ready. First one, and then the other nodded. 'Now!' Bella said and let go.

Write a short story about a man walking down a road. Give it a mysterious ending.

Nigel set off at a fair trot. He'd put on his favorite loafers and his lovely brown cardigan. It was a cool day, but that didn't faze him at all. The wind danced over his bald head, and tussled his limp and greasy hair.

Nigel was in a fantastic mood today. He felt truly alive for the first time in 40 years. As an accountant, there wasn't a huge amount of variation or interest in his work. Numbers came in, and these days robots did all the work. Never mind, Nigel kept walking. 

He recalled better times when his hair had been thicker and his belly tighter. He was the master of the calculator, a colossal computer that sang machine rhythm for him and him alone. 

In a way, Nigel reflected, he had been the architect of his own downfall. He made a machine that made him redundant. It doesn't even make him rich. But that's Luddite nonsense. If you're a plow maker, making a plow-making machine doesn't make you redundant, it makes your job more ... future-y. 

The road bent and he could see the long straight of the beach up ahead. Long straight gravel road. Long straight horizon. He smelled the salty sea air. 

He managed to get to the little place after Marg passed. She had never wanted to live at the beach, and that was fair. It is inconvenient to be so far from the semblance of civilization, but there it was. The sea. 

The sea called to Nigel. When he was young, it had called him away to America. When he was finished getting his fancy degrees, it called him home. Now the sea called to him again, so Nigel kept walking.  

The crunch of gravel gave way to the soft pushing of buffalo grass, then the squish-crunch of sand. The bay embraced him in a grey arc, bounded on both ends by tall, withering cliffs. 

Nigel walked a little further and felt his loafers dampen with the salt water. Soon he felt his knees and skin prickle with the lapping water. Then his cardigan got wet. Then his grizzled chin and his lank hair became the playthings of the sea. 

Nigel kept walking.
