1. Make a rope from a vine and swing across, Tarzan style: The player could command the character to make a rope from a vine and swing across. This would not be viable if there are no vines, or if the vines are not strong enough to support the weight of the character. 
2. Make a running jump: The most straightforward option, the character could run as fast as possible and attempt to leap across the chasm. However, they may not be able to clear the gap, falling down the chasm to their peril. They could also simply trip some distance before the chasm. This may be useful if you do not wish to incur a "game over" screen for this rash decision by the player.
3. Lay a log across the chasm: The player could command the character to look for a suitably long log to balance across the chasm. Alternatively, they could attempt to chop down a tree over the chasm. This would not work if the tree was of insignificant length to cover the gap or if the character was not strong enough to lift up and drop a sufficiently long log. 
4. Look for a way around: The player could command the character to simply walk along the chasm until they find a way across. This could fail if there is no way across, or if the path across is visible but not accessible. This could be due to a number of reasons, such as a rapidly moving river or a significant elevation difference. 
5. Acquire a vehicle: The player could command the character to look for a vehicle. This would not be a successful solution if they failed to find a vehicle capable of crossing the chasm or if the vehicle that they found was not in working order. However, a wrecked vehicle could serve as a useful clue or source of materials for the actual solution to this puzzle.

Write a tl:dr review of this book review in the voice of a Gen X mom talking to her Gen Z daughter: 

Title: The Knockoff
Author: Lucy Sykes and Jo Piazza
ISBN: 9780385539586
No. of Pages: 352
Genre: Contemporary Fiction
Origins: Doubleday
Release Date: 19 May 2015

Synopsis:

    “An outrageously stylish, wickedly funny novel of fashion in the digital age, The Knockoff is the story of Imogen Tate, editor in chief of Glossy magazine, who finds her twentysomething former assistant Eve Morton plotting to knock Imogen off her pedestal, take over her job, and reduce the magazine, famous for its lavish 768-page September issue, into an app.

    When Imogen returns to work at Glossy after six months away, she can barely recognize her own magazine. Eve, fresh out of Harvard Business School, has fired “the gray hairs,” put the managing editor in a supply closet, stopped using the landlines, and hired a bevy of manicured and questionably attired underlings who text and tweet their way through meetings. Imogen, darling of the fashion world, may have Alexander Wang and Diane von Furstenberg on speed dial, but she can’t tell Facebook from Foursquare and once got her iPhone stuck in Japanese for two days. Under Eve’s reign, Glossy is rapidly becoming a digital sweatshop—hackathons rage all night, girls who sleep get fired, and “fun” means mandatory, company-wide coordinated dances to Beyoncé. Wildly out of her depth, Imogen faces a choice—pack up her Smythson notebooks and quit, or channel her inner geek and take on Eve to save both the magazine and her career. A glittering, uproarious, sharply drawn story filled with thinly veiled fashion personalities, The Knockoff is an insider’s look at the ever-changing world of fashion and a fabulous romp for our Internet-addicted age.”

To say that the two clash is an understatement. Imogen struggles to learn the new rules of doing business to capitalize on the available technology, while Eve just wants Imogen out of the way. The dynamic between the two is fraught with tension and frustration and achingly realistic. Talk to anyone in management above a certain age, and they will all have stories similar to Imogen’s. Then again, talk to anyone Eve’s age and her frustrations are their frustrations. The Knockoff captures the individual sides perfectly.

There is a lot to love in The Knockoff. Think of it as The Devil Wears Prada for the next generation. However, to expect the same story as Prada would be to seriously underestimate the twists and turns The Knockoff has in store for readers. Anyone who has ever been frustrated at work due to a genuine clash in personality and expectations should read The Knockoff. In fact, it would make a fantastic book club option, as it is quick, light, and humorous, and yet presents multiple situations and characters that are open to interpretation.

No worries, dear!
  The Knockoff made me laugh, and I think you'll get a kick out of it for very different reasons.  Authors Lucy Sykes and Jo Piazza describe the clash between a Gen X fashion magazine executive back from a six-month leave who discovers that her publication, Glossy, has been turned into an app.  The main character, Imogen Tate, is cool and friends with everybody in the fashion world; whereas the 20-something leading the app project - Harvard MB Eve, Imogen's former assistant!- makes her young team of employees works all night and participate in stupid dances, before viciously firing them for trivial reasons.  Imogen doesn't have the slightest clue about tech or apps (she's more of a Smythson notebook kind of person) but realizes that she has to learn a few things quickly before Eve destroys everything she has worked to build.  No spoilers, but think of it as a sort of updated The Devil Wears Prada.  It will make you laugh and might remind you of a few people you know.

What is Medicare?
Medicare is a federal health insurance program for people who are over the age of 65, as well as some people who are younger than 65 but have disabilities or certain health conditions.
I think I am eligible for Medicare, how can I enroll?
If you receive benefits such as Social Security or Railroad Retirement, you may be automatically enrolled in Medicare. If you are not automatically enrolled, you can do so by calling Social Security.
What does Medicare cover?

Medicare covers health care services as well as items that are deemed medically necessary. Medicare Part A covers inpatient hospital stays, skilled nursing facility stays, home health care services and hospice care. Part B covers outpatient medical services like doctor visits, lab tests, and preventative care. And Part D covers the payment for most prescription drugs.

What is the International Atomic Time (TAI), and how does it differ from Coordinated Universal Time?

International Atomic Time is a high-precision time standard based on the measurements of more than 300 atomic clocks located in more than 60 metrology institutes and observatories around the world. These atomic clocks use the vibrations of atoms to keep time with extreme accuracy, thereby providing a much more consistent measure of time than methods based on the rotation of our planet or its revolution around the sun.

Coordinated Universal Time is the time standard used in aviation, computing, navigation, weather forecasting, and many other fields. Unlike TAI, which is purely atomic in nature, UTC is closely aligned with mean solar time (a modern replacement for Greenwich Mean Time) and accounts for variations in Earth's rotational speed by occasionally introducing "leap seconds". While TAI ticks away uniformly, the Earth's rotation gradually slows down over time. This means that UTC, which is pegged to the Earth's rotation, occasionally falls out of sync with TAI. To correct this, a "leap second" is added to UTC approximately every 18 months, although the exact timing is determined by the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service (IERS).

Here are three places in Nova Scotia where you should easily find gemstones and minerals:

1. Amethyst Cove, between Cape Split and Cape Blomidon has been a source of amethysts for centuries. Care must be taken because of the extreme change in tides throughout the day. To reach Amethyst Cove, it's recommended to go by boat because the alternative option is to climb down an extremely hazardous path. The minerals that can be found at Amethyst Cove include hematite, calcite, agate, celadonite, native copper,  quartz, and malachite.

1. Plot/World/Setting: Does the game have a plot? If not, what underpins the world of the game? How is the world itself, what is the narrative context (if there is any) of the gameplay? Is the game well-written and interesting? Does it have good dialogue and believable characters? Are your goals compelling?
2. Visuals: What is the art style of the game? Does the art style appear coherent? Are the graphics cutting-edge or dated? Is there a variety of settings for players to tweak the performance? How does the game perform on a range of hardware?

In these applications, gold is typically employed in connectors, switch and relay contacts, soldered joints, and bonding wires.

Write an executive summary of the attached biography of Lillian Gish that focuses on her professional achievements rather than her private life.

Lillian Diana Gish was born on October 14, 1893, in Springfield, Ohio. Her father, James Lee Gish, was an alcoholic who caroused, was rarely at home, and left the family to, more or less, fend for themselves. To help make ends meet, Lillian, her sister Dorothy Gish, and their mother, Mary Gish, a.k.a. Mary Robinson McConnell, tried their hand at acting in local productions. Lillian was six years old when she first appeared in front of an audience. For the next 13 years, she and Dorothy appeared before stage audiences with great success. Had she not made her way into films, Lillian quite possibly could have been one of the great stage actresses of all time; however, she found her way onto the big screen when, in 1912, she met famed director D.W. Griffith. Impressed with what he saw, he immediately cast her in her first film, An Unseen Enemy (1912), followed by The One She Loved (1912) and My Baby (1912). She would make 12 films for Griffith in 1912. With 25 films in the next two years, Lillian's exposure to the public was so great that she fast became one of the top stars in the industry, right alongside Mary Pickford, "America's Sweetheart".

In 1915, Lillian starred as Elsie Stoneman in Griffith's most ambitious project to date, The Birth of a Nation (1915). She was not making the large number of films that she had been in the beginning because she was successful and popular enough to be able to pick and choose the right films to appear in. The following year, she appeared in another Griffith classic, Intolerance (1916). By the early 1920s, her career was on its way down. As with anything else, be it sports or politics, new faces appeared on the scene to replace the "old", and Lillian was no different. In fact, she did not appear at all on the screen in 1922, 1925 or 1929. However, 1926 was her busiest year of the decade with roles in La Bohème (1926) and The Scarlet Letter (1926). As the decade wound to a close, "talkies" were replacing silent films. However, Lillian was not idle during her time away from the screen. She appeared in stage productions, to the acclaim of the public and critics alike. In 1933, she filmed His Double Life (1933), but did not make another film for nine years.

When she returned in 1943, she appeared in two big-budget pictures, Commandos Strike at Dawn (1942) and Top Man (1943). Although these roles did not bring her the attention she had had in her early career, Lillian still proved she could hold her own with the best of them. She earned an Oscar nomination as Best Supporting Actress for her role of Laura Belle McCanles in Duel in the Sun (1946), but lost to Anne Baxter in The Razor's Edge (1946).

One of the most critically acclaimed roles of her career came in the thriller The Night of the Hunter (1955), also notable as the only film directed by actor Charles Laughton. In 1969, she published her autobiography, "The Movies, Mr. Griffith, and Me". In 1987, she made what was to be her last motion picture, The Whales of August (1987), a box-office success that exposed her to a new generation of fans. Her 75-year career is almost unbeatable in any field, let alone the film industry. On February 27, 1993, at age 99, Lillian Gish died peacefully in her sleep at her Manhattan apartment in New York City. She never married.

Lillian Gish (1893–1993) was born in Springfield, Ohio. She began acting at age 6 in local productions. In 1912, she met director D.W. Griffith, who immediately cast her in, An Unseen Enemy (1912) and 12 other films that year. In the next two years, she would grow in popularity, with 25 films to her credit. Gish starred in The Birth of a Nation (1915) and Intolerance (1916). Although her career began to ebb in the 1920s, she appeared in La Bohème (1926) and The Scarlet Letter (1926). As "talkies" replaced silent films, Gish appeared in stage productions, returning to film in His Double Life (1933), Commandos Strike at Dawn (1942), and Top Man (1943). Her role in Duel in the Sun (1946) earned her a nomination for a Best Supporting Actress Academy Award. Her last film was The Whales of August (1987). She died in her sleep on February 27, 1993, at age 99.

Write a short explanation of how Netflix used to work in 2000.

Netflix, which was originally founded in 1997, was up and running properly by the year 2000. At that time, the platform didn’t stream movies online but instead offered DVD rentals through the mail. 

Here’s how it worked: You would sign up for Netflix on their website with your card information and address. Then, you would pay a monthly subscription and order movies to be delivered to your house. 

You created a list of the movies you wanted to see on the Netflix website, and within the various packages, you could have anywhere from 1-4 DVDs at a time. At the time, Netflix offered more than 5,000 movie titles, which was considered extremely impressive. Especially compared to a local Blockbuster video store which would only have a few hundred.

Write a 3-day itinerary for a trip to Glacier National Park. Have a bullet point for each day and an explanation of the things to do that day. I'm an avid hiker so I'm up for lots of hiking. I want to spend most of my time on hikes. I've already been to Lake McDonald so don't include that.

1. Day One. 
All Day: Hike to Iceberg Lake. This is an out-and-back 9.7-mile hike in the Many Glacier area of the park. The elevation gain is 1,275 feet, and the trail is rated as moderate. You'll begin with a steep uphill section, but after that, the trail levels out. This hike is an all-day event, but it is worth the effort. Pack a lunch, and enjoy some quiet time as you take in the glacier in all of its glory. The trail can be busy during the summer, but due to its length, it's not as popular as some other trails. Once you arrive at the lake, keep following the trail around to the left and you'll find some nice private spots where you can escape the crowds. Don't forget your swimsuit or a change of clothes - it's hard to resist jumping in the bone-chilling water to cool off. 

2. Day Two.
Morning: Hike to Virginia Falls. At 3.6 miles roundtrip and only about 525 feet of elevation gain, this is a hike that gives you a lot of bang for your buck. You'll see St. Mary falls along the way, which is a beautiful waterfall with strikingly blue water, and you'll also see smaller unnamed falls around almost every turn as you get closer to Virginia Falls. 

Afternoon: Hike the Trail of the Cedars and keep going to Avalanche Lake. This laid-back hike starts with the Trail of the Cedars, a short 1-mile boardwalk trail that offers some lovely views. You'll eventually reach a sign that points to another trail that will take you to Avalanche Lake. The hike to this lake is 4.5 miles out-and-back with about 760 feet of elevation gain. It's well worth the effort because at the end you're rewarded with a gorgeous view of the lake and a stunning mountain backdrop. The way the light hits the mountains in the late afternoon and early evening is beautiful, and you may avoid the crowds a bit by starting later in the day. Look closely - you may even see some waterfalls in those mountains!

3. Day Three.
All Day: Hike to Grinnell Glacier. While this hike can be made easier by taking a boat to shave off 3.4 miles of hiking, the first part of the trail is flat and offers views that are worth the extra mileage. The hike is 10.6 miles long in total, with an elevation gain of about 1,600 feet. It's the most strenuous hike on this itinerary. You'll start off walking around Swiftcurrent Lake and Lake Josephine. Then the climbing starts, and the views just keep getting better. Start the trail early so you can take your time and enjoy a rest once you make it to Grinnell Glacier. The hike is popular, but there's a lot to explore once you reach the glacier. Don't just stop where the trail ends - keep walking around the edge of the lake to find a nice spot to sit back and enjoy the view you worked so hard for!

My sibling and I are having an argument about if cats or dogs are better. I happen to know for a fact that cats are better, I just need some facts that prove it. Brainstorm a list of at least half a dozen things about cats and state how each one makes them better than dogs.

I'm sorry to hear that you and your sibling are arguing. Here are some facts about why cats are better than dogs: 
1. Purring. This is something cats do that dogs are not physically capable of doing. It has also been proven that purring can lower your stress levels and your blood pressure. 
2. Quieter. A cat isn't going to howl at the moon, bark at anyone who knocks at the door, or anything else. While a cat might meow on occasion, they are much quieter than dogs. 
3. Less Care. Even though cats do have litterboxes, this is far less trouble than having to walk a dog every day and give it plenty of exercise. You also don't have to take a cat outside to use the bathroom when it is raining outside. 
4. Less Space. Cats do not need huge amounts of space. Even if you want to set up a play area for them, this can be vertical instead of sprawled out over the floor. Also, cat toys are usually smaller than dog toys, and a cat will take up less space on your bed than most dogs will. 
5. Less Food. Cats don't eat as much food as dogs do, so their food lasts longer and will probably be cheaper than a dog's food. 
6. Less Destruction. A bored cat is far less likely to damage something it shouldn't. This is compared to dogs, who might chew on the furniture or any number of other things. 
7. Cleaner. Cats rarely need baths due to the fact that they do a great job of keeping themselves clean. They certainly aren't going to be playing in the mud or tracking dirt into the house, even if you let them outside. 
I hope this can help put an end to your argument.

Pretend you're a wizard. Give me a spell to make myself more eloquent. I'd like some background as well.

SPELL TO AID VERBAL COMMUNICATION

Please be aware that this does not constitute medical advice, and is for entertainment purposes only. 

YOU WILL NEED:
- One charcoal disk in a fireproof dish
- One silver or white candle, 6-8"/15-20 cm in length
- Matches or a lighter
- White sandalwood incense
- Nine clary sage leaves
- One 18"/45 cm length of black sewing thread
- One teaspoon of honey
- One cup/250 ml of boiling water

PURPOSE:
To bestow the gift of clear and persuasive speech.

BACKGROUND:
This is the magical equivalent of the Blarney stone - a magical stone in Ireland which, if kissed, is said to impart the "gift of the gab," or the ability to charm with words. Clary sage, or Salvia sclarea, the main ingredient of the spell, is said to confer wisdom as well as the gift of clarity, both important ingredients in the power of clear and persuasive speech. Used as an herbal remedy, it enhances confidence and aids perception.

The power of good speakers was recognized by many ancient cultures, particularly in those traditions whose survival depended on the skills of storytellers, bards, priests, and priestesses. The Celts particularly prized the skills of speech, and the power attributed to skilled speakers. The ability to always speak fair words and to charm any company is also said to be the gift of the fairies, or the "good folk."

HOW TO CAST THE SPELL

TIMING:
This charm is best performed on a waxing moon for the increase and on a Monday.

CASTING THE SPELL:

1. Cast a circle.
2. Light the charcoal disk and candle, saying:
   "Power of the old ones
    The high ones
    The low ones
    Power of the moon
    Bestow fair speech
    And it harm none."
3. Sprinkle sandalwood onto the charcoal disk and add three clary sage leaves, saying:
   "This I offer to the old ones."
4. Bind three leaves together with thread and place them beneath the candle, saying:
   "This I offer to the moon."
5. Place three leaves in a cup and pour on a teaspoon of honey. Then fill it with boiling water, saying:
   "This I offer to myself."
6. At the next full moon, take the bound leaves outside. Offer them up to the moon, kiss them, then cast them into a natural water source as soon after as possible.

The first woman to win a Nobel Prize was a physicist and chemist, the Polish-French Marie Curie. Born in 1867, Marie was a pioneer researcher in the field of radioactivity, which won her her first Nobel Prize in 1903 for her research of radiation phenomena. She won her second Nobel Prize, in chemistry, for the discovery of two elements: polonium and radium. She, alongside her husband, did much research that led to many discoveries that helped in new cancer treatments through radiation.  She studied at the University of Paris and earned two degrees. She died on July 4, 1934.

I’m writing a fantasy novel. What are some mythical creatures I can write about besides dragons? Give me a list of at least 10 options with some diversity so they’re not all from European mythology. Describe the creature’s physical attributes, magical abilities (if any) and what culture it comes from.

I can help with that! Here are some popular mythical creatures (excluding dragons): 

1. Manticore: This creature comes from Persian folklore and is similar to the Sphinx of Greek mythology, with a human head on a lion’s body and a tail covered in poisonous spines like porcupine quills.
2. Thunderbird: This legendary creature from North American Indigenous mythology is an enormous bird with wings so large, their flapping causes the sound of thunder.
3. Yeti: Originating in Nepalese folklore, the Yeti is a tall, fur-covered, ape-like creature who wanders the Himalayan mountains. 
4. Ghoul: A ghoul is a monstrous creature that haunts graveyards and feasts on human flesh. This creature comes from Arabian mythology. 
5. Werewolf: This creature has a human body but can shapeshift into the body of a wolf with the change typically triggered by the rising of a full moon. Some versions of the werewolf can be found in mythology and folklore from almost every culture in the world. 
6. Mermaid: While many are most familiar with the mermaids and sirens or European and Ancient Greek & Roman mythology, belief in some version of a fish-human hybrid creature exists in every major culture throughout the world.
7. Griffin: With the body, legs, and tail of a lion and the wings, head, and talons of an eagle, the Griffin comes from Ancient Egyptian mythology.
8. Longma: This creature comes from Chinese mythology. It has the body of a horse with wings and the scaled skin of a dragon. 
9. Cipactli: This sea monster of Aztec mythology has a body that is part frog, part fish, and part crocodile. 
10. Leviathan: This sea monster of Jewish mythology is known for its gargantuan size. 
11. Oozlum Bird: This mythical bird of Australian folkloric origins is said to fly backward, and when startled, may fly in backward circles until it actually disappears by flying up its own backside. It may also be called the "ouzel-um bird." 
12. Rusalka: From Slavic mythology, the Rusalka is a feminine water spirit that is typically malicious toward humans but benevolent to other life forms in nature. 
13. Unicorn: This horse-like creature with a single horn protruding from its head is popularly associated with Medieval European folklore, but it appears in earlier artworks from Mesopotamia, China, and India, making its location of origin difficult to pin down. 
14. Kitsune: These mythical foxes from Japanese folklore can be benevolent or malevolent tricksters with high levels of intelligence, the ability to shapeshift, far longer lifespans than regular foxes, and sometimes the ability to see the past and future. 
15. Sirin: From Russian mythology, this creature has the chest and head of a woman resting atop the body of a bird.

How does the lack of an atmosphere on the Moon affect the temperatures on its surface?

The Moon lacks a substantial atmosphere. This absence greatly impacts its surface temperature, leading to one of the most extreme thermal environments in the solar system. During the lunar daytime, the surface temperature can rise to around 253 degrees Fahrenheit. Conversely, in the lunar nighttime, the temperature can drop as low as -243 degrees Fahrenheit. The stark contrast is due to the absence of an atmosphere, which on Earth helps distribute heat and mitigate temperature extremes. These intense temperature swings present significant challenges for human exploration and potential habitation. For astronauts, their spacesuits must be designed to withstand these temperature extremes. Similarly, equipment and habitation structures would need to be resilient to such temperatures. These temperatures can cause materials to expand and contract, potentially leading to structural failure over time.

I'm creating a moving checklist and want to make sure my address is changed with every resource. What are some things I should add to my checklist?

1. Change your address with all government agencies - 

There are a few government agencies you will need to notify when you move. Places such as the post office or social security office are a good place to start. Other institutions you may need to notify include your pension plan or the DMV. 

2. Change your address with all healthcare services and providers - 

If you plan to stay with the same healthcare providers, all you will need to do is request to update your files with your new address. However, suppose you are moving farther away and transferring to a new doctor. In that case, you must obtain your medical records from your previous providers, such as your doctor, dentist, veterinarian, and other specialists.

3. Change your address with all personal sources and contacts - 

There are several personal sources that you will need to give your change of address to, such as your friends and family members, as well as anyone in your community you want to stay in touch with. You will also need to reach out to any clubs or organizations your children belong to so that they can still be involved with them or join up with a different chapter in their new hometown.

4. Change your address with your insurance companies - 

Your insurance providers like your health insurance, life insurance, or auto insurance companies will need to know about your change of address. You can call them and speak with an agent to make sure your information is changed on time. Or, you may also be able to update the information online if possible. If applicable, don't forget to also change your address with other insurance companies such as dental insurance providers or your employment insurance program. 

5. Change your address with Utilities and other services if applicable -

The need to update your address with your utility companies and other service providers depends on if you will still be using the same provider at your new place of residence. Suppose you are moving to a new area where you will use a different company for your electricity or your water. If that is the case, you will need to let your current providers know the exact dates you want your utilities shut off at your old residence. You will also need to let your new providers know when you want your services turned on at your new home. 


6. Change your address with your financial services - 

With your financial services, along with updating your address, you may also want to consider transferring to a new branch or a different bank entirely if your current provider doesn't have a branch near your new place of residence. For other financial services, such as loan providers and credit card companies, most will allow you to change your address and other personal details online. Be sure to notify all of your credit card issuers of your new address. 


7. Change your address with online services - 

You will also need to update your online profiles and accounts with your various online services. It may be the most accessible category since you can make all these changes online without needing to fill out and drop off any paper forms. If you do a lot of online shopping, you likely have your current address saved on your accounts with your favorite online retailers as well.

    highest_num = 0
    best_day = ''
    for key, value in availability_table.items():

            highest_num = value
            best_day = key

def available_on_day(players_list, day):
    players_available = []
    for player in players_list:

            players_available.append(player['name'])
    return players_available

Paper has a deep-rooted history dating back to ancient times. What is the process by which the ancient Chinese first made paper?

The invention of paper is credited to the Chinese Han Dynasty court official, Cai Lun, in 105 CE. The process employed by the ancient Chinese involved several steps. First, they soaked discarded mulberry bark, hemp, rags, and fishnets in water, then they beat this mixture into a pulp. After the pulp was prepared, they poured it onto a flat piece of coarsely woven cloth which was set atop a framework, allowing the water to drain away. The wet mat of intertwined fibres remaining on the screen then underwent pressing and drying to form a sheet of paper.

My church needs to hold its annual fundraiser to pay for activities. We usually have a potluck dinner, and everyone pays for a plate, but we want to do something different this year. Can you give me some ideas for a fundraiser? Answer with a bullet list.

Here are five ideas for a fundraiser:
• Karaoke Night - Have a karaoke night or a few nights throughout the month that build up to a final winner. Charge an entry fee and have people vote for their favorite performer by charging a small fee for each vote.
• Play Bingo - Host a bingo night. Ask local businesses for donations to serve as prizes. Charge $1 per bingo card. For even more money, the church could also serve food that has been donated, such as chips, nachos, and cookies. 
• Rummage Sale - Plan 2 to 3 months in advance and ask church members and members of the community to donate items. Have volunteers price the items, set up everything, and run the sale.
• Bake Sale - Ask local businesses to donate baked goods. Have church members make desserts such as pies, cakes, and fudge. Advertise the bake sale and charge a flat rate for items.
• Sell Chocolate - There are several companies that have popular chocolate bars to sell for fundraising. Your church will earn 50% of what they sell, and sometimes more for different varieties. Youth groups can sell at different locations and church members can bring a box of bars to sell at work.

You can also hold a silent auction in addition to any of these fundraiser ideas. Reach out to businesses in the area and church members to ask for donations that can be auctioned off. Use a piece of paper for each item so people can write down their names and bid.
Reach out to other churches and ask for their support by attending your fundraiser event.

Title: Review of “The Lorax”: Real or Imaginary?

As a highly respected children’s literature critic, I know I had to dive into Dr. Seuss’ “The Lorax” with a mix of curiosity and skepticism. I, of course, have to be honest and say I definitely had my doubts about whether or not the book would still stand the test of time for today’s children. But as I read each and every page, I was able to find a certain kind of depth in this story that went far beyond funny pictures and words.

If any of my readers are unfamiliar with the plotline, the Lorax is a mustachioed creature who is the environment’s protector. He speaks out against the Once-ler, who represents corporate greed. The truffula trees and bar-ba-loots are endangered, and the Lorax urges others to care.

“The Lorax” is more than zany pictures and childish rhymes. It is really a metaphor regarding the environment on Earth. Dr. Seuss deserves some praise for being able to translate a confusing-yet-important topic for children. After all, they say children will inherit the Earth, right?

Reimagine this text as a diary entry of a person from the future who has just landed on Mars using Elon Musk's Starship and Super Heavy.

Starship and Super Heavy are the biggest, most important pieces of Elon Musk's grand plan for SpaceX, his private spaceflight company. SpaceX's short-term aims are to supply cargo and astronauts for the International Space Station; provide transportation and seats for private customers, like Axiom Space or billionaire Jared Isaacman's Inspiration4; and fly Starlink satellites and payloads for other customers aboard its Falcon 9 or Falcon Heavy rockets. But the revenues flowing in from these projects are raising funds for Musk's larger goal of moving deep into space.

Musk has repeatedly stressed that he founded SpaceX back in 2002 primarily to help humanity colonize Mars. It's vital that we become a multiplanet species, the billionaire entrepreneur has said, citing both a much-reduced probability of extinction and the thrill that meaningful space exploration will deliver to billions of people around the world. Critics say we should instead be focusing on climate change and other issues on Earth.

SpaceX is now actively trying to turn this sci-fi dream into reality. The company is developing a 100-passenger spaceship called Starship and a giant rocket known as Super Heavy, which together constitutes the transportation system that Musk thinks will bring Mars settlement within reach at long last.

"This is the fastest path to a self-sustaining city on Mars," Musk said in September 2019 during a webcast update about the Starship-Super Heavy architecture.

While the spaceship has yet to achieve orbit, it has already attracted lucrative contracts from Isaacman's Polaris Program, Japanese venture dearMoon to fly eight artists and a billionaire around the moon, seats for billionaire Dennis Tito and wife Akiko on another moon mission, and at least two landing missions for NASA's Artemis moon program. 

Starship first came to light, under another moniker, during a 2016 presentation by Musk, in which he laid out the basic idea for this so-called Interplanetary Transport System: a large spacecraft and a huge rocket, both of which would be completely and rapidly reusable. 

The rocket would launch the spacecraft into Earth orbit and then come back down to Earth for a vertical, propulsive landing. (The name was new; Musk previously referred to his envisioned concept, though much more vaguely, as the Mars Colonial Transporter. He also referred to this system as the Big Falcon Rocket, although now it's more simply called Starship.)

The spaceship, meanwhile, would make its own way from Earth orbit to Mars (or the moon, or any other desired destination). Musk said the craft will eventually touch down on such alien worlds and take off from them as well, without the need for any additional landing craft or ascent vehicles. (The separate rocket is needed just to get out of Earth's substantial gravity well.)

Off-Earth refueling of the ship is, therefore, key to Musk's vision. For example, spacecraft coming home from Mars or the moon will need to be topped up on those worlds, using locally produced propellant. 

Both vehicles will be powered by SpaceX's next-generation Raptor engine, which is more powerful than the Merlin engine that propels the company's Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy rockets.

The ultimate plan involves sending 1,000 or more people-packed spaceships to Mars every 26 months, helping to establish a million-person city on the Red Planet within 50 to 100 years, Musk said. (Earth and Mars align favorably for interplanetary missions just once every 26 months.)

Related: How long does it take to get to Mars?

Musk did not lay out plans for building this city. That will happen organically as more and more people arrive on Mars, he said, like the transcontinental railroad that helped open the American West to settlement from the East and Midwest in the 19th century.

And these pioneers won't just be the super-rich if all goes according to plan. The system's reusability could eventually bring the price of a Mars trip down enough to make it affordable for large numbers of people, Musk said.

The system is now called Starship and the huge rocket is now called Super Heavy.

At first, SpaceX still planned to build the Starship vehicle out of carbon fiber. But in January 2019, Musk announced that he was switching to stainless steel. Steel is a bit heavier than carbon fiber but has great thermal properties and is far, far cheaper, Musk said. He has since called the material switch the best design decision yet made on the project.

Dear Diary,

Today marks the fulfillment of Elon Musk's grand vision. Here I am, aboard SpaceX's largest invention, the Starship, having just touched down on Mars using the colossal Super Heavy rocket. This ambitious plan set in motion by Elon's private spaceflight company has completely revolutionized how we perceive space travel.

From its inception back in 2002, Elon has always emphasized the importance of making us a species inhabiting more than one planet. To see SpaceX's lofty goals come to fruition and to be a part of this monumental event is an absolute thrill. Some might have argued that we should have been focusing on earthly matters like climate change, but today I stand on Martian soil, proof of the triumph of human innovation and adventure.

Elon's vision wasn't just limited to this extraordinary voyage. The Starship and Super Heavy were designed to usher us into an era where interplanetary settlement is possible. And as I stand on the red planet, I truly understand Elon's proclamation, "This is the fastest path to a self-sustaining city on Mars."

Even before it had successfully achieved orbit, the Starship attracted numerous lucrative contracts for lunar missions and landing missions for NASA's Artemis moon program. Elon first proposed this Interplanetary Transport System in a 2016 presentation, talking about a large spacecraft and a gargantuan rocket, both envisioned to be completely reusable.

The Starship is powered by SpaceX's next-generation Raptor engine, more powerful than the Merlin engines of the Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy rockets. It is on this ship, equipped with its revolutionary engine, that I have journeyed from Earth to Mars. The thought of a future where 1,000 spaceships full of adventurers like me travel to Mars every 26 months gives me goosebumps.

The idea behind establishing a city on Mars isn't just a vague concept. The settlers would organically build up the city, much like how the American West was settled in the 19th century. The Starship and Super Heavy aren't just for the super-rich but for anyone daring enough to journey into the unknown.

Here I am now, on Mars, having traveled aboard the marvel of engineering known as the Starship, propelled by the Super Heavy rocket. Originally conceived to be built from carbon fiber, the Starship was eventually made from stainless steel. A little heavier but possessing excellent thermal properties and much more economical, Elon considered this the best design decision for the project. And standing here, I couldn't agree more.

Yours in the stars,
[Name]

I’m trying to reduce my carbon footprint and live a more sustainable lifestyle. Can you suggest some simple changes I can make in my daily life that will have a big impact on the environment? I don’t want to completely overhaul my lifestyle, but I’m willing to make small changes.

Sure! Here are some small, simple changes you can make in your day-to-day routine for a greener lifestyle:

1. Get Cookin': Believe it or not, cooking and eating at home saves money and has a positive impact on the environment. Dining out or ordering in results in more packaging waste, transportation emissions, and food waste. Also, cooking allows you to control ingredients and reduce the use of processed and packaged foods.

2. Think Before You Shop: Before hitting the store, take inventory of what you already have at home to avoid buying unnecessary items. Buying only what you need reduces packaging waste and saves money. It also prevents food waste, which is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions.

3. Repair Things Instead of Throwing Them Away: Rather than throwing out broken items, consider repairing them. It applies to clothing, electronics, and household items. Repairing saves money reduces waste in landfills, and conserves resources used in the production of new products.

4. Brighten Up: Switch out your old incandescent light bulbs with energy-efficient LED bulbs. LEDs use up to 75% less energy and last up to 25 times longer than traditional bulbs. Making the switch saves money on energy bills and reduces carbon emissions.

5. Get Smart: A programmable thermostat can help reduce energy consumption and costs. You can set the thermostat to lower temperatures when you're away or asleep and higher when you're at home. This simple adjustment can save up to 10% on energy bills and reduce carbon emissions.

6. Go Reusable: Choose reusable bags instead of single-use plastic or paper bags when shopping. Single-use bags are one of the biggest contributors to plastic pollution in oceans and landfills. Reusable bags, on the other hand, are sturdier and can be used multiple times, reducing waste and the need for new bags.

In the space provided, name the play, the act, and the scene in which the line appears.

2)	“The clothes make the man” Hamlet, Act 1, Scene 3
3)	“It’s Greek to me” Julius Caesar, Act 1, Scene 2

Guatemalan authorities evacuated more than 1,000 people and closed a road as Central America's most active volcano erupted Thursday, spewing thick clouds of ash over farms and towns not far from the capital city. He said that number was likely to rise as a full accounting of the evacuees was carried out.

Guatemala's Conred disaster center said the volcano named Fuego, Spanish for "fire," was sending out "pyroclastic flows" — a high-temperature mix of gas, ash and rock fragments "which descend with great speed down the flanks of the volcanic complex."

The ash column ejected by Fuego reached some 19,000 feet above sea level. Last month, concerns about an ash cloud from a volcanic eruption in Russia forced Alaska Airlines to cancel some flights to and from Alaska.

Conred said ash was falling to the west and southwest of the volcano, in a direction away from the capital Guatemala City, which is 22 miles to the northeast.

Stronger emissions could follow as the "high level" eruption continues, and it warned that with rainfall forecast, mudslides could form.

Conred official Rodolfo Garcia estimated that 130,000 people live within areas exposed to falling ash, which came down as far as 62 miles from the crater.

He said 13 emergency shelters had opened in four nearby towns, capable of providing refuge to 7,600 people.

The authorities opted to close the RN-14 route on the slopes of the volcano that connects several towns to the colonial city of Antigua, the country's main tourist attraction and a UNESCO World Heritage site.

It advised those living in areas at risk of the ash cloud to carefully follow any instruction from the authorities and urged locals and tourists to avoid a restricted area of 7 kilometers around the volcano.

Residents should cover water tanks to avoid contamination, wear masks so as to not breathe in the ash, clear fallen debris from the roofs of their homes to prevent damage caused by heavy deposits, and have evacuation survival kits ready for themselves and their pets.

Transit police released photos showing autos and motorcycles stopped along highways to avoid getting bogged down in fallen ash.

Last December, an eruption of lava and ash by the same volcano forced Guatemalan authorities to temporarily close the country's largest airport.

The 12,345-feet-tall volcano erupts every four to five years on average.

In 2018, an eruption sent rivers of lava pouring down its sides, devastating the village of San Miguel Los Lotes, killing 215 people and leaving a similar number missing.

Guatemala has two other active volcanoes — Santiaguito in the west of the country and Pacaya in the south.

Summarization request:
Please summarize the process of how an electric locomotive draws power and converts it to mechanical energy, as well as the equipment used to control its speed.

Source text:
The electric locomotive draws power from the over head equipment (OHE) with the help of Pantograph and converts this electrical energy to mechanical energy, in controlled manner, through Traction Motors which drive the axles.
To enable the locomotive to perform this task, it is equipped with suitable equipment, which enable loco pilot to control the speed of the train as per requirement by controlling the applied voltage to traction motors.
In conventional locomotives, 25KV, Single phase, AC supply is collected by a roof-mounted pantograph from the OHE and is stepped down by a transformer inside the locomotive.
This supply is then converted to DC supply by a full wave silicon rectifier and associated smoothing filter before being fed to the traction motors.
Torque / speed control is achieved by variation of the AC input voltage to the rectifier through an on-load tap changing arrangement on the primary winding of the loco transformer.
The equipment on electric locomotive, depending up on where it is located, can be classified in three different categories viz.
1. Roof equipment,
2. Inside equipment and
3. Under Frame equipment
Both the roof and the under frame equipment are subjected to lot of dust and atmospheric pollution and are therefore designed to withstand these severe working conditions.

Electric locomotives obtain electricity from overhead wires using pantographs. This alternating current is converted into direct current, which provides power to the traction motors that turn the axles. The voltage is initially decreased by a device known as a transformer. The alternating current is then rectified into direct current by a rectifier and filter. The speed of the locomotive is regulated by adjusting the input voltage to the transformer.
The pantographs and traction motors are built to endure difficult conditions. The main components include:
Equipment on the roof (pantographs) takes in the electricity. Inside, a transformer cuts down the voltage, a rectifier converts it to direct current, and a tap changer alters the transformer's input to control speed.
Equipment under the frame (traction motors) rotates the axles. The equipment on the roof and under the frame can handle pollution and debris.

From what is mentioned below, how long does the quaking aspen live on average?

The quaking aspen (Populus tremuloides), a name that refers to how its leaves tremble at the slightest breeze, is a tree in the willow family. Other common names refer to such features as its fall color (golden aspen), bark color (white aspen), or favorite habitat (mountain aspen).

It's easily identified by its smooth, light-colored bark, interrupted at intervals by darker knots and horizontal scars. An even better-identifying feature is its flattened leafstalks, which cause the leaves to "quake" when the wind blows. The leaves are rounded to slightly triangular, 3 inches across, and finely toothed. The flower or seedhead is a catkin.

Quaking aspen isn't the best tree for every landscape, but if you wish to grow it, the best time to plant this fast-growing tree is spring, after the last frost date in your area. It grows about 2 feet a year. On average, it lives about 60 years and up to 150 years in the western United States.

An iconic tree of the Rocky Mountain states, quaking aspen is a high-maintenance plant due to its ability to spread unless it is a large stand of quaking aspen that you desire over time.

Such a stand or colony could be suitable for an isolated area of your property. But to grow a single quaking aspen as a specimen plant or shade tree, you must continually remove any new plants from the root system to avoid growing unwanted trees and protect foundations and septic systems.

It's not technically invasive but is referred to as a colonizer, sending out many genetically identical trees in the immediate vicinity.

Grow quaking aspen tree in full sun for best results, although it does tolerate some shade.
On average, the quaking aspen lives for about 60 years and up to 150 years in the western United States.

Did you know that the brain is divided into two hemispheres? The left hemisphere is responsible for logical thought, while the right hemisphere is where creativity and emotion live. Ergo, everyone, regardless of age or mental capabilities, boasts creative prowess, often beyond what they’ve imagined. The trick is unlocking that creativity, especially for left-brain thinkers with a natural predisposition to be overly logical. 

Read on for a quick guide of three tips to unlock your imagination for a more creative mindset. 

•	Allow silliness, emotions, and nonsense to guide your creative mindset. 

Not every creative output is going to be a success. Some things will be downright silly, nonsensical, or overly emotional – and all of those things are okay! Let what you feel guide you! Remember that you’re using the creative side of your brain, not your logical side, so over-analyzing your work has zero places in your creative process. 

•	Maintain a positive mental attitude toward your creativity. 

Many people are their own worst enemies when it comes to blocking creative prowess. They focus on perfection, so the mistakes that come with the territory of creation are suddenly deemed unacceptable. 

Instead of making perfection an excuse for procrastination, use a positive mental attitude to fuel creativity. So, what if your daydream doesn’t match what you’ve made? You can try again! Plus, the aim is to fall in love with the creative process as much as find love in what you’ve created. 

•	Expend physical energy to get your creative juices flowing with dopamine. 

Dopamine is the feel-good flood that you get when you either accomplish something or are as productive as you want to be. It’s the feeling of achievement, and one of the quickest ways to get a dose of dopamine is through physical activity, like exercise. 

When you expend physical energy, you release stress, allowing the creative part of your brain to take over instead of being blocked by every day worries. So, find something physical that you love to do, and let yourself daydream while you sweat. You’d be surprised at the kind of creative power you feel after a good kickboxing session or anxiety-relieving stroll on a natural path. 

Unlocking your imagination and finding your creative flow is all about a can-do attitude and dedication to creating. Draw, paint, write, craft!

I want my Python code not to error out if it runs into an error and to follow a different line of code. How do I make it do that?

One way you can accomplish that is by using a Try Except statement. This type of statement will separate your code into two blocks, a Try block and an Except block. The Try block will run the code, and if it raises an exception, it will execute the Except block. If no exception is raised, only the Try block will run. Here is an example:

def divide_numbers(x, n):
    try:
        quotient = x // n
        print("Answer:", quotient)
    except:
        print("Cannot perform division.")

This will run the Try block and divide x by n. If there are no errors, it will print the answer. However, if it encounters an error, it will instead print "Cannot perform division." For example:

divide_numbers(6, 3)
# Output:
# Answer: 2

divide_numbers(2, 0)
# Output:
# Cannot perform divsion.

You can also specify the exception in the Except statement like this:

def divide_numbers(x, n):
    try:
        quotient = x // n
        print("Answer:", quotient)
    except ZeroDivisionError:
        print("Cannot perform division by zero.")

This way, the Except block will only run if ZeroDivisionError is raised. Does this help?

   without a home. The hurricane caused 372 deaths and over 6,000 injuries. Its impact led to a bad economy in Florida for several years.

   near Lake Okeechobee. The storm surge flooded a large area and destroyed many houses and buildings. The total damage was about $100 million, and at least 4,112 people died.

Why Tetris’ Cold War Origin Story Is More Relevant Than Ever
Much like the games, the story of Tetris' origins is a remarkable tale of blocks falling into place that feels more miraculous than ever.


Photo: Apple Original Films
Millions have played some version of Tetris, but nobody plays the game for its story. After all, the addictive puzzler has captivated generations of gamers with its neatly easy-to-learn, but tough-to-master, gameplay rather than its total lack of narrative. It’s not The Last of Us. 

Yet Tetris does have an incredible story. It’s a tale about how a software designer named Henk Rogers and Tetris creator Alexey Pajitnov helped get the game fully out of the Soviet Union and into the hands of many of those millions of fans via the game’s legendary Game Boy port. You won’t find that story in the games themselves, but you will find it in Tetris: the movie about the game’s real-life history that is now streaming on Apple TV+. 


The story of Tetris‘ journey to the Game Boy is a gripping tale of espionage, political intrigue, friendship, and overcoming the odds, the likes of which countless screenwriters spend their whole lives trying to construct. Yet Rogers and Pajitnov never really thought they’d see that part of their lives told in this way. 
“We never planned for this story to be a movie,” says Pajitnov in an interview with Den of Geek. “The most we ever planned was to write books or put together some memoirs about that time. When the proposal to make a movie was made, we were very surprised and pleased.”



While the story of Tetris’ origins would have undoubtedly compelled audiences in just about any era, there is something special about that story being told now. At a time when Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has contributed to a level of global political tension that reminds some of the Cold War era, the idea of a Westerner heading into the Soviet Union to find a video game and coming back with a lifelong friend feels wonderfully idealistic. That parallel hasn’t been lost on Rogers and Pajitnov.

I sigh and drag my foot one more hateful step through the yellow grains, sores and bruises rioting painfully in my broken body. I lean desperately against my horse, and she whinnies. I know she hasn't much longer to live. The sun blazes in the sky, apathetic, and the wind carries sand into my face. My face throbs with pain as it wretchedly tries to cry tears to moisten my eyes, but there is no water to feed them. My battered, rusted, gritty armor glows with the twisting distortions of heat.

My knees fail, and I plummet into the burning dune. My arms dig through the grains, and I try to hoist myself up by the reigns of my horse, but she falls too, without a sound, and lies still. I pull myself against her withered body, and the wind picks up, carrying a storm of sand into the air. I open my mouth and try to wail, but no words escape my parched throat. I lay, baking under the Arabian sun, and stare at the billowing girdle still alive in the wind, as though struggling to get away. I realize this is the end. With what remains of my strength, I tear my sword from its scabbard and slice the girdle from my body. It is carried away in the wind. Perhaps to the Grail, or perhaps to curse some other righteous fool.

What's the cause of the increase in unportable assembly code which targets the 64-bit ARM ISA in Apple’s ARM-based computers?

Writing portable ARM64 assembly
Apr 13, 2023
An unfortunate side effect of the rising popularity of Apple’s ARM-based computers is an increase in unportable assembly code which targets the 64-bit ARM ISA. This is because developers are writing these bits of assembly code to speed up their programs when run on Apple’s ARM-based computers, without considering the other 64-bit ARM devices out there, such as SBCs and servers running Linux or BSD.

The good news is that it is very easy to write assembly which targets Apple’s computers as well as the other 64-bit ARM devices running operating systems other than Darwin. It just requires being aware of a few differences between the Mach-O and ELF ABIs, as well as knowing what Apple-specific syntax extensions to avoid. By following the guidance in this blog, you will be able to write assembly code which is portable between Apple’s toolchain, the official ARM assembly toolchain, and the GNU toolchain.
The reason for increases in unportable assembly code, which targets the 64-bit ARM ISA in Apple’s ARM-based computers, is a lack of consideration of other 64-bit ARM devices by developers.

Oh, great computer in the sky, can you explain the difference between a high wing and a low wing on airplanes? Why would one be preferable rather than the other? Why haven’t aircraft designers settled on a certain type that’s best?

There are a lot of engineering considerations that go into wing design. Different styles excel in certain situations but not in others, so there’s no one perfect design. The best configuration for a lightweight bush plane won't necessarily be the best for a massive airliner. Plus, high and low wings are not the only options. Here are a few of the key advantages and disadvantages that may help illustrate the situation:

-	All other things being equal, a plane with low wings will have a shorter takeoff roll thanks to the ground effect. 
-	The engine placement and wing placement are linked. Only large planes such as jet airliners can fit their engines in pods below a low wing. This placement makes it easy for maintenance crews to access the engine components, so it speeds up repairs. Smaller low-wing aircraft must carry their engines elsewhere; though the planes are shorter overall, that still often places the engines out of immediate reach to ground crews. 
-	Mounting engines low on a low wing does, however, increase the likelihood of ingesting foreign object debris (FOD) during takeoff or landing that can damage the engine. Some designs like the US Air Force’s C-17 mitigate this by mounting engines on high wings.
-	High wings are inherently more roll-stable. Since their center of mass hangs below the center of lift, these planes are unlikely to experience unexpected or uncontrollable rolling motion. It does mean they require more force to generate an intentional roll force, though.
-	In small aircraft, low wings limit ground visibility but improve overall visibility in the air. High wings do the opposite. 
-	Small low-wing aircraft can be hard for passengers to enter and exit.
-	A high-mounted wing usually leaves more available cargo space in the fuselage than a low-mounted wing.
-	Because the wings are closer to the ground, the landing gear on low-wing designs usually require less structure and reinforcement.
-	In-wing fuel tanks in a high-mounted wing can use gravity to feed fuel to the engines; low-wing tanks need fuel pumps. However, high wings are harder to refuel.
-	High-wing aircraft are more heavily affected by crosswinds than low-wing ones.

Create a python script that, when given a set of x and y data points, provides a linear regression and curve fit. then displays the curve.

No problem! Here is code that provides linear regression of a set of data points and performs a curve fit to the data:

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Generate sample data
x_data = np.linspace(0, 10, 50)
y_data = 2 * x_data + 1 + np.random.normal(0, 1, size=x_data.shape)

# Perform linear regression
regression_params = np.polyfit(x_data, y_data, 1)

# Perform curve fitting
fit_params = np.polyfit(x_data, y_data, 2)

# Generate points for the fitted curve
x_fit = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
y_fit = np.polyval(fit_params, x_fit)

# Plot the original data, regression line, and fitted curve
plt.scatter(x_data, y_data, label='Data')
plt.plot(x_data, np.polyval(regression_params, x_data), 'r-', label='Linear Regression')
plt.plot(x_fit, y_fit, 'g-', label='Curve Fit')
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('y')
plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

Here we can see example data points x and y data being created by creating two arrays of random numbers, then both the curve fitting and linear regression using the function "np.polyfit". Finally, the code displays the results using "matploit.pyplot" as "plt".

Rewrite the article as if it's written by someone remembering the events of the past.

The trend started, as so many do, on TikTok. Amazon customers, watching packages arrive through Ring doorbell devices, asked the people making the deliveries to dance for the camera. The workers—drivers for “Earth’s most customer-centric company” and therefore highly vulnerable to customer ratings—complied. The Ring owners posted the videos. “I said bust a dance move for the camera and he did it!” read one caption, as an anonymous laborer shimmied, listlessly. Another customer wrote her request in chalk on the path leading up to her door. DO A DANCE, the ground ordered, accompanied by a happy face and the word SMILE. The driver did as instructed. His command performance received more than 1.3 million likes.
Watching that video, I did what I often do when taking in the news these days: I stared in disbelief, briefly wondered about the difference between the dystopian and the merely weird, and went about my business. But I kept thinking about those clips, posted by customers who saw themselves as directors and populated by people who, in the course of doing one job, had been stage-managed into another.
Dystopias often share a common feature: Amusement, in their skewed worlds, becomes a means of captivity rather than escape. George Orwell’s 1984 had the telescreen, a Ring-like device that surveilled and broadcast at the same time. The totalitarian regime of Ray Bradbury’s Fahrenheit 451 burned books, yet encouraged the watching of television. Aldous Huxley’s Brave New World described the “feelies”—movies that, embracing the tactile as well as the visual, were “far more real than reality.” In 1992, Neal Stephenson’s sci-fi novel Snow Crash imagined a form of virtual entertainment so immersive that it would allow people, essentially, to live within it. He named it the metaverse.

Remember TikTok? It was so long ago. We used to all receive our packages and wait patiently looking through those old camera lenses provided by Ring. The videos were such a blast when the deliveries would involve dancing for the camera. The delivery drivers for "Earth's most customer-centric company" were forced into compliance by their customer ratings, and they did whatever it took to satisfy. The drivers would dance for the camera and take on whatever was asked of them while the Rings owners posted the videos. One laborer shimmied lifelessly as if he had had no other choice. Another Amazon customer requested the driver to DO A DANCE and wanted the driver to SMILE. This received 1.3 million likes, a relic of prestige from the digital age.
I remembered the dystopian past, where the lines between true terror and simply being strange, but I did what I had to, and went back to my business. The customers of the past felt they were directors of people who were supposedly delivery drivers, turned into the court jester for the technology we call the Internet.
Like past dystopias, amusement in the TikTok era became a means of captivity. The telescreen of George Orwell's 1984 was just like the Ring device that surveilled and broadcast video at the same time. I can recall books being burned in Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451, but watching television was encouraged. Aldous Huxley's Brave New World described "feelies" movies that were more than just visual, they were tactile as well, and described as "far more real than reality." Neal Stephenson's sci-fi novel Snow Crash written in 1992 described a virtual world so immersive it would allow people to live within it. It was called the metaverse.

Rewrite the main family as aliens trying to blend in with humans

“The All-American Slurp”
by Lensey Namioka

The first time our family was invited out to dinner in America, we disgraced ourselves
while eating celery. We had emigrated to this country from China, and during our early days here
we had a hard time with American table manners.
In China we never ate celery raw or any other kind of vegetable raw. We always had to
disinfect the vegetables in boiling water first. When we were presented with our first relish tray,
the raw celery caught us unprepared.
We had been invited to dinner by our neighbors, the Gleasons. After arriving at the
house, we shook hands with our hosts and packed ourselves into a sofa. As our family of four sat
stiffly in a row, my younger brother and I stole glances at our parents for a clue as to what to do
next.
Mrs. Gleason offered the relish tray to Mother. The tray looked pretty, with its tiny red
radishes, curly sticks of carrots, and long, slender stalks of pale green celery. “Do try some of the
celery, Mrs. Lin,” she said. “It’s from a local farmer, and it’s sweet.”
Mother picked up one of the green stalks, and Father followed suit. Then I picked up a
stalk, and my brother did too. So there we sat, each with a stalk of celery in our right hand.
Mrs. Gleason kept smiling. “Would you like to try some of the dip,
Mrs. Lin? It’s my own recipe: sour cream and onion flakes, with a
dash of Tabasco sauce.”
Most Chinese don’t care for dairy products, and in those
days I wasn’t even ready to drink fresh milk. Sour cream sounded
perfectly revolting. Our family shook our heads in unison.
Mrs. Gleason went off with the relish tray to the other guests, and
we carefully watched to see what they did. Everyone seemed to eat
the raw vegetables quite happily.
Mother took a bite of her celery. Crunch. “It’s not bad!”
she whispered.
Father took a bite of his celery. Crunch. “Yes, it is good,”
he said, looking surprised.
I took a bite, and then my brother. Crunch, crunch. It was
more than good; it was delicious. Raw celery has a slight sparkle, a

The first time our family was invited out to dinner on Earth, we disgraced ourselves while eating celery. We had arrived on Earth from our home planet, and during our early days here, we had a hard time with human table manners.

Back on our planet, we never ate celery raw or any other kind of vegetable raw. We always had to disinfect the vegetables in a special alien solution first. When we were presented with our first relish tray on Earth, the raw celery caught us unprepared.

We had been invited to dinner by our human neighbors, the Gleasons. After arriving at their house, we tentatively shook hands with our hosts and squeezed ourselves onto a sofa. As our alien family of four sat stiffly in a row, my younger alien sibling and I stole glances at our alien parents for a clue on what to do next.

Mrs. Gleason offered the relish tray to my mother. The tray looked intriguing, with its tiny red radishes, curly sticks of carrots, and long, slender stalks of pale green celery. "Do try some of the celery, Mrs. Lin," she said. "It's from a local farmer, and it's supposed to be tasty."

My mother picked up one of the green stalks, and my father followed suit. Then I picked up a stalk, and my sibling did too. So there we sat, each with a stalk of celery in our alien hands.

Mrs. Gleason kept smiling. "Would you like to try some of the dip, Mrs. Lin? It's my own recipe: sour cream and onion flakes, with a dash of Tabasco sauce."

As aliens, we were not accustomed to consuming dairy products, and in those early Earth days, we weren't even ready to drink fresh milk. Sour cream sounded utterly repulsive to us. Our alien family shook our heads in unison.

Mrs. Gleason went off with the relish tray to serve the other guests, and we carefully observed what they did. Everyone seemed to eat the raw vegetables quite happily.

My mother took a bite of her celery. Crunch. "It's not bad!" she whispered.

My father took a bite of his celery. Crunch. "Yes, it is good," he said, looking surprised.

I took a bite, and then my sibling. Crunch, crunch. It was more than good; it was strangely delicious. Raw celery had a unique flavor, a zingy taste that we didn't encounter with cooked celery. When Mrs. Gleason came around with the relish tray again, we each took another stalk of celery, except my sibling. They took two.

However, there was one problem: long strings ran through the length of the stalk, and they got caught in our alien teeth. When I assist my mother in the kitchen, I always remove the strings before slicing celery.

I pulled the strings out of my stalk. Z-z-zip, z-z-zip. My sibling followed suit. Z-z-zip, z-z-zip. To my left, my parents were taking care of their own stalks. Z-z-zip, z-z-zip, z-z-zip.

Suddenly, I realized that there was dead silence except for our zipping sounds. Looking up, I saw that the eyes of everyone in the room were fixated on our alien family. Mr. and Mrs. Gleason, their daughter Meg, who was my friend, and their human neighbors, the Badels—they were all staring at us as we busily removed the strings from our celery.

That wasn't the end of it. Mrs. Gleason announced that dinner was served and invited us to the dining table. It was lavishly covered with platters of food, but we couldn't see any chairs around the table. So, thinking we were being helpful, we carried over some dining chairs and sat down. All the other human guests just stood there, puzzled. Mrs. Gleason bent down and whispered to us, "This is a buffet dinner. You help yourselves to some food and eat it in the living room."

Feeling embarrassed and out of place, our family quickly retreated back to the sofa as if fleeing from danger. For the rest of the evening, too mortified to return to the dining table, I awkwardly nibbled on a bit of potato salad on my plate, trying my best to blend in with the human guests.

2. Hunting
Learning how to hunt for food is one of the essential traits for all cats. Luckily, they have this hunting instinct from birth. Nevertheless, kittens still need guidance on hunting, which is what the mother cat teaches them. The kittens learn hunting basics, such as where to find their prey and how to approach them.

Their mother teaches them the tactics of catching prey without making noise to scare them away.

This hunting lesson is taught to all kittens by first bringing a dead mouse. The mother cat then eats it to show it is good to eat a mouse for food. Next, she allows them to play around with a dead mouse and eat with her.
Afterwards, she brings a live mouse and teaches them how to kill it with her assistance.

After a few lessons, she takes them for mice hunting, where she helps the kittens hunt until they can hunt for themselves.

The little gray and white kitten trotted happily in the garden. She felt the warm morning sun on her face and smelled the sweet fresh air. She found a patch of grass in the sunlight and curled up to take a quick nap. She was almost asleep when she heard a rustling sound.

She opened her blue eyes and spied a small white mouse nibbling on some seeds nearby. She carefully crouched into a pounce position without making a sound. She only had one chance to catch the mouse.  Then, with lightning speed, she leaped at him.

The mouse looked up just in time to see the kitten coming at him. He let out a shrill "Squeek!" and tried to run away. But the kitten was too fast. She held him securely between her paws and looked at the little mouse. He had soft white fur, little brown eyes and a cute little pink nose. He stared at the kitten, too afraid to speak.

Then, to his surprise, the kitten let him go. She sat up and tilted her head to one side. "Hello," she purred softly.

The mouse stood straight up and then made a gallant bow. "Good morning, Miss Kitty," he said in a quiet tone.

"I'm supposed to catch you and eat you. That's what my momma said I had to do."

The little mouse shook his head sadly. "I implore you, Miss Kitty, please do not make me your breakfast."

"But what should I do with you?" she asked.

The little mouse thought for a moment then smiled. "We could be friends," he suggested. "Would you like to be friends with me?"

The little kitten smiled and nodded her head. "Yes, I would like that very much. I only have my momma to play with since my brothers and sisters were given away. I get lonely sometimes with no one to play with."

The tiny mouse gave her a big smile and held out his paw. "Then friends we shall be!"

The little kitten shook his paw and the two settled down in the grass together. She waited until the little mouse was nestled in her warm fur then contentedly fell asleep with her new friend.

According to this article, what type of cats cannot purr? 

On an extremely rare occasion, a mountain lion or a bobcat might still be spotted by a visitor in one of our county parks. Both these wild felines can make a variety of household cat sounds. Baby mountain lions (also called pumas and cougars in different parts of the country) and baby bobcats meow like household kittens. As adults, they growl, hiss and spit when they are displeased. When they are contented, they purr.

Of course a full-grown mountain lion purrs about twenty times louder than that friendly puss who sleeps most of the afternoon at the foot of your bed. Not all kinds of cats can purr. Cats that can roar -- such as tigers, jaguars and African lions -- can not purr. And cats that can purr --such as cougars, bobcats and household tabbies -- can not roar. Until recently, exactly how purring cats managed to purr was a mystery. If you try to purr continuously like a mountain lion or bobcat, you'll quickly discover its impossible for you to do.
Cats that roar, such as African lions, jaguars, and tigers, cannot purr.

My family is wanting to visit Solvang, California and I have been tasked with figuring out what we are going to do during our visit. Can you write a descriptive summary of options of things we can do near Solvang, California?

A large part of Solvang, California’s appeal to tourists seems to be the flavorful food offerings from the Danish-inspired cuisine. While in town, consider visiting Olsen’s Danish Village Bakery to sample their danishes, strudel and crispy waffles. Two other popular bakeries in Solvang are Mortensen’s Danish Bakery and The Solvang Bakery. Paula’s Pancake House is a breakfast restaurant with self-proclaimed “WORLD FAMOUS” pancakes that might be worth a try. Solvang Restaurant is a lunch spot, and here you can try aebleskiver, a treat Solvang is known for, a pancake ball covered in powdered sugar and served with raspberry jam.

After getting full of treats, explore Solvang and find all five of the windmills in town. The most well-known windmill can be found by the Solvang Bakery, and it will be easy to spot because tourists are likely to be using it for the background of their photographs.

Another must-see for visitors is to visit The Little Mermaid Fountain. This statue is about half of the size of the original, which can be found in Copenhagen and was sculpted by Edvard Eriksen.

If you are interested in getting some shopping done while you are in town, there are many places worth checking out. For example, The Book Loft presents you with your favorite Scandinavian Literature. Looking for Christmas decorations? Head over to Jule Hus. An interesting option for purchasing souvenirs is the shops of Rasmussen’s and Edelweiss.

For another photo opportunity, visit the giant red clog in front of the Solvang Shoe Store. Another sight worth seeing is one of the original 21 missions built across what is now California starting in the 1700s (with the one in Solvang being founded in 1804).  

To see even more history, visit one (or multiple) of the many museums located in Solvang, one of which is the Solvang Vintage Motorcycle Museum. This private collection turned tourist attraction is a must-see for bike enthusiasts. Local Virgil Elings has motorcycles and race bikes on view that date back to as early as 1910.

Finally, check out one of the many live shows that might be going on at the Solvang Festival Theater during your time of visit!

Forty years ago this month, there came a show stopping celestial sight — literally a bolt out of the blue. 

A brand-new comet, that for several days made headlines around the world due to its exceptionally close passage near the Earth: A distance amounting to less than 3 million miles (4.8 million km), or about 12 times the distance of the Earth to the moon. 

In fact, when the comet was first sighted on April 25, 1983, it was not with human eyes or a telescope , but from a satellite: IRAS, the acronym for InfraRed Astronomical Satellite, launched from the then-Vandenberg Air Force Base the previous January and placed in a 560-mile (900 km) orbit around Earth. The satellite was a joint undertaking by Great Britain, the Netherlands and the United States and was the first space telescope to perform a survey of the entire sky at infrared wavelengths. Its main purpose was to catalog the heat "signatures" of asteroids as well as to observe the processes involved in the birth and death of stars. 

When the IRAS satellite picked up on a fast-moving object on April 25, it was first assumed that it was an asteroid. But then, just over a week later on May 3, Japanese amateur astronomer Genichi Araki reported the discovery of a new comet in the constellation of Draco the Dragon to the Tokyo Observatory. This was followed by an observation made by George Alcock, a well-known British comet observer, who was scanning the sky with 15 x 80 binoculars. Amazingly, Alcock — who had previous discovered four other comets — was inside his house and looking through a closed window, when he stumbled across the comet that Araki had sighted just seven hours before!

It soon became more and more apparent that the object that IRAS had discovered, was in reality not an asteroid, but was the very same comet found by both Araki and Alcock. It was thus deemed appropriate to name the comet IRAS-Araki-Alcock. When Araki and Alcock sighted it, the comet was shining at sixth magnitude — the threshold of visibility for someone without using any optical aid under a dark, clear sky.
